The study uses an fMRI task involving perception of biological motion (socially relevant nonverbal human action cues) contrasted with scrambled motion, and reports ROIs/coordinates in pSTS, amygdala, and fusiform that are core social-information processing regions. Thus the analysis pertains to measuring neural responses to social information (biological motion selectivity).

Although social-network measures are collected, the fMRI contrast/analysis summarized in this table concerns perceptual responses to biological vs scrambled motion and does not involve tasks or contrasts about bonding, attachment, close others, cooperation/competition, or affiliation-based social interactions.

Biological motion point-light displays index reception of non-facial social communicative signals (body movement/action cues). The analysis/contrast (biological > scrambled motion) captures neural processing of nonverbal communicative information, and reported ROIs/coordinates reflect this social-communication processing network.
The task does not require self-referential judgments, self-knowledge, or agency-related processing; it is focused on perceiving others' movements (biological motion) vs scrambled motion.

The biological motion vs scrambled motion contrast measures action/animacy perception and decoding of others' actions, engaging pSTS and amygdala; thus it directly measures perception and understanding of others.

Participants performed an explicit facial emotion labeling task (happy faces vs neutral), which is a social-emotional processing paradigm requiring perception/interpretation of social cues (facial expressions).
The contrast tests processing of facial emotion expressions, not bonding/attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-specific affiliation cues (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

Labeling facial expressions engages receptive facial communication (decoding facial affect), a core component of social communication; HA>NE isolates emotional facial content relative to neutral faces.
Task requires judging others’ facial emotions, not self-referential evaluation, agency, or self-knowledge.
Participants infer and categorize others’ emotional states from faces (happy vs neutral), directly measuring perception/understanding of others.
Angry vs neutral faces during explicit emotion labeling is a social-emotional perception task measuring social processing of facial cues.
No manipulation of attachment/affiliation (e.g., close other, bonding, cooperation/competition); only emotion perception.
Decoding angry facial expressions reflects receptive facial communication; AN>NE isolates socially communicative affect signal in faces.
Contrast does not involve self-focused judgments or awareness of one’s own states.
Requires perceiving/understanding another person’s emotional state (anger) from facial expression.
Fearful vs neutral faces during emotion labeling is a classic social perception task relying on interpreting others’ facial affect.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation; stimuli are generic faces with emotional expressions.
Fearful facial expressions are communicative social signals; FE>NE indexes receptive facial communication processing.
Does not assess self-perception/agency/self-knowledge; focuses on others’ expressions.
Participants evaluate others’ emotional state (fear) from facial cues; FE>NE measures understanding of others.
Regression of HA>NE activation on TAS-20 total examines individual differences in social-emotional face processing during explicit labeling.
Individual-difference regressor is alexithymia; the task/contrast does not involve attachment/affiliation contexts or relationship cues.
Targets receptive decoding of facial affect (happy vs neutral) with modulation by alexithymia—still a social communication measure.
Although alexithymia is a self-trait, the neural contrast reflects processing of others’ faces, not self-referential judgment during scanning.
Emotion labeling of others’ happy faces (HA>NE) is perception/understanding of others; regression tests how this varies with alexithymia.
Regression of AN>NE activation on TAS-20 total indexes individual differences in neural response during angry facial emotion labeling, a social processing task.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation; regression pertains to facial affect perception and alexithymia.
Angry faces are facial communicative signals; AN>NE with alexithymia modulation assesses receptive facial communication processing.
Analysis concerns processing of others’ emotional expressions, not explicit self-appraisal tasks.
Participants infer others’ anger from faces; regression tests perception/understanding of others varying with alexithymia.
Regression of FE>NE activation on TAS-20 total assesses individual differences in social-emotional face processing during explicit labeling of fearful expressions.
Task is not about bonding/attachment; it is facial emotion perception with an alexithymia regressor.
Fearful facial expressions are key inputs to receptive facial communication; FE>NE with modulation by TAS-20 total measures this construct.
No self-perception/agency manipulation during the fMRI contrast; it targets others’ faces.
Labeling fear in another’s face is direct perception/understanding of others; regression assesses variation with alexithymia.
Regression of HA>NE activation on TAS-20 DDF examines social-emotional face processing during explicit emotion labeling as a function of alexithymic traits.
No affiliation/attachment content; DDF is an individual-difference measure and the stimuli are generic emotional faces.
Measures receptive facial communication (decoding happy expressions) modulated by difficulty describing feelings.
Despite using a self-trait regressor (DDF), the task contrast pertains to perceiving others’ expressions rather than self-judgment.
HA>NE requires perceiving others’ emotional state; regression tests how that neural processing varies with TAS-20 DDF.
Regression of AN>NE activation on TAS-20 DDF evaluates individual differences in social-affective face processing during angry emotion labeling.
Angry vs neutral face processing does not index attachment/affiliation constructs.
Angry facial expressions are social communicative cues; AN>NE with DDF modulation assesses receptive facial communication.
No self-related judgments during scanning; regressor is trait but the measured process is other-face perception.
Task involves understanding others’ anger from faces; regression quantifies association with DDF.
Regression of FE>NE activation on TAS-20 DDF probes individual differences in social-emotional face processing during fear labeling.
No relationship/attachment manipulation; focuses on emotion perception and alexithymia subscale.
Fearful faces convey socially relevant information; FE>NE with DDF modulation is receptive facial communication.
Not a self-referential task/contrast; it is about perceiving others’ expressions.
Participants infer fear in others from facial cues; regression tests dependence on DDF.
Regression of HA>NE activation on TSIA-DDF assesses how individual differences in alexithymia relate to social-emotional face labeling responses.
No affiliation/attachment paradigm; TSIA-DDF is a trait regressor and stimuli are emotional faces.
Happy face decoding is receptive facial communication; the regression still measures this communicative processing.
Although TSIA-DDF indexes self-related difficulty describing feelings, the in-scanner process measured is perception of others’ facial affect, not self-perception.
HA>NE reflects understanding others’ emotional state; regression tests modulation by TSIA-DDF.
Regression of AN>NE activation on TSIA-DDF evaluates individual differences in social processing of angry facial expressions during explicit labeling.
Contrast/regression does not involve affiliative bonds or attachment-related stimuli; it is emotion perception.
Angry faces are salient facial communication cues; AN>NE with TSIA-DDF modulation captures receptive facial communication processing.
No self-knowledge/agency task; alexithymia regressor does not convert the contrast into self-perception.
Participants interpret others’ anger from faces; regression links this to TSIA-DDF.
Regression of FE>NE activation on TSIA-DDF tests how alexithymic features relate to neural processing during labeling of fearful expressions, a social perception task.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation; focuses on decoding emotional expressions.
Fearful facial expressions are part of receptive facial communication; FE>NE with TSIA-DDF modulation measures this construct.
Analysis measures responses to others’ faces, not self-referential processing.
Inferring fear from another’s facial expression is perception/understanding of others; regression assesses association with TSIA-DDF.

Task manipulates social context of communication (friend vs computer) and contrast tests sender-related processing within a social communication paradigm, engaging mentalizing network.
Contrast directly compares messages believed to come from a real-life friend versus a computer, probing processing modulated by an affiliative bond (friendship) and social closeness.
Stimuli are communicative text messages; contrast isolates effects of communication source (human friend vs computer) during message reception/attribution.

Although participants judge who sent the message, the contrast does not require self-referential evaluation of one's own traits/states; it targets sender (other) vs computer context rather than self-knowledge/agency.

Friend vs computer engages reasoning about another agent as communicative source and recruits mentalizing network; the contrast measures processing of information attributed to another person (vs non-agent).

Although MVPA decodes message content invariant across sender, it is performed within an explicitly social communication task context (messages believed from friend or computer) and measures processing of communicative social stimuli.
This analysis decodes happy vs sad across senders (cross-sender), explicitly aiming for sender-invariant content representation; it does not test affiliation/bond differences (friend vs other).
Decoding concerns the content of received text messages (non-facial communication) within a communication paradigm, i.e., receptive social communication processing.
No self-referential judgment or self-state representation is tested; classification is of message valence/word content in visual regions.
Happy vs sad word decoding in ventral occipitotemporal cortex reflects sensory/lexical content processing; it is explicitly invariant to sender and does not assess others' mental states/traits.
MVCA tests sender-dependent gating of content-specific information flow (friend vs computer) during communication, a core social processing manipulation.

Connectivity difference (friend minus computer) operationalizes modulation by an affiliative relationship (real-life friend) versus non-social source, and is further linked to friendship closeness in the study.
Assesses how the brain gates information during reception of communicative text messages depending on source; directly targets communication-related network coupling.
Primary effect concerns source-dependent coupling and encoding, not self-reflection, self-traits, or agency; participants are receivers judging sender identity.
Friend (intentional agent) vs computer manipulation engages understanding of another person's communicative intent/mental states and modulates dmPFC coupling (mentalizing-related).

Contrast isolates neural activity for responding to joint attention in a social interaction (RJA) relative to a non-social control (RJAc), directly measuring social processing during interactive joint attention.

Task is cooperative but contrast tests social joint attention responding vs non-social control, not attachment/affiliative bonding or relationship/kinship manipulation (no loved-one/attachment style/close bond measure).

RJA specifically requires reception of communicative gaze cues (gaze following after mutual gaze) in an interactive context; the contrast targets communicative aspects of joint attention beyond non-social cueing.

Although responding involves action/agency, the contrast is not designed to measure self-agency or explicit self-referential judgment; it primarily targets processing of others' communicative gaze and social interaction demands.

Responding to another agent’s gaze bid requires representing the partner’s attentional state/intent and interpreting gaze as communicative; contrast subtracts matched non-social cueing, emphasizing understanding of others in social context.

Contrast isolates neural activity for initiating joint attention in a social interaction (IJA) relative to a non-social control (IJAc), thus measuring social processing during interactive joint attention initiation.

Despite cooperative game context, contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no bonding/relationship manipulation or attachment measures); it targets communicative initiation vs non-social control.
IJA is production of a communicative gaze bid to direct another’s attention (initiating joint attention); the contrast targets productive social communication beyond non-social task demands.

Initiation entails goal-directed action but is not an explicit self-perception/agency judgment task; primary construct is communicative signaling to another rather than self-knowledge or self-agency evaluation.

Successful initiation requires monitoring and modeling the partner’s attentional readiness (mutual gaze) and interpreting their subsequent gaze response; thus involves understanding others' attentional state/intent.

Conjunction identifies voxels commonly engaged by both responding and initiating joint attention (each relative to matched non-social controls), capturing core social-processing network for joint attention.
Common activation across RJA and IJA reflects joint attention communication and social cue processing, not attachment, bonding, or affiliative relationship processes.
Conjunction reflects shared receptive/productive communicative processes of joint attention (mutual gaze, gaze following/leading) beyond non-social controls.
While joint attention can involve self-other coordination, this conjunction is not specifically designed to assess self-referential processing, self-knowledge, or explicit agency attribution.

Shared network likely supports representing the partner’s attentional state/intent (e.g., pSTS/TPJ involvement) common to both initiating and responding; contrast removes non-social attentional demands.

Interaction contrast compares social components of initiating vs responding joint attention after subtracting matched non-social controls, testing differential social-processing demands by social role.
Although cooperative context remains, the contrast is about initiation vs response mechanisms in joint attention, not affiliative bonding/attachment constructs.
Directly contrasts productive communicative signaling (IJA) vs receptive responding (RJA) components of joint attention, isolating additional communication-related processes for initiation.
Contrast does not explicitly operationalize self-awareness or self-agency judgments; differences likely reflect communicative production/control demands rather than self-perception per se.
Initiating vs responding still depends on monitoring the partner and predicting/assessing their attentional state changes; contrast may reflect added modeling of the other during initiation.

Task involves evaluating whether the participant feels addressed by a communicating actor; contrast isolates effect of co-speech iconic gestures within a social-communicative context, thus measuring social cue processing.

No manipulation or measurement of bonding/attachment, affiliation, kinship, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship stimuli; gestures vs no-gesture does not operationalize affiliation/attachment.
Stimuli are communicative video utterances with/without co-speech gesture; IC>NG targets processing of non-facial communicative signals (gestures) during speech in a communication task.

Although participants make an addressment judgment, IC>NG primarily indexes perception/integration of others’ gestures with speech rather than self-knowledge/agency or explicit self-referential processing.
Contrast captures increased processing of another person's actions/gestures (action perception) and communicative intent cues relative to no gesture.
Orientation (egocentric vs allocentric) manipulates being directly addressed in social communication and engages social-cue evaluation; contrast measures social processing of addressment cues.
Egocentricity/addressment does not assess social bonding or attachment relationships; no affiliation/attachment manipulation.
Body orientation is a communicative cue (addressment) in a conversation-like setting; ego>allo measures processing of nonverbal communicative orientation cues.
Egocentric orientation increases self-involvement/being addressed; contrast likely captures self-referential appraisal of being the addressee (self-related involvement) within the task.
Determining addressment from orientation requires perceiving the actor’s stance and inferring communicative intent (understanding mental states/action perception).
Allocentric vs egocentric orientation contrast still pertains to processing of social communicative addressment cues (less-direct addressment), hence within social processing domain.
No attachment/affiliation constructs or close-relationship stimuli are involved.
allo>ego isolates neural responses to nonverbal communicative orientation away from participant (addressment cue), a component of social communication processing.
This contrast relates to diminished self-addressment/self-involvement when the actor is oriented away; still a self-relevance manipulation embedded in the addressment task.
Requires perceiving actor orientation and interpreting communicative intention directed to someone else (understanding others’ intent).
Interaction tests how body orientation effects depend on gesture context for feeling addressed; directly targets social-cue integration underlying social processing.
No bonding/attachment or relationship content; interaction concerns addressment cues rather than affiliation.
Measures integration of two communicative cues—body orientation and co-speech gesture—central to non-facial social communication.

Specifically contrasts egocentric vs allocentric addressment in presence vs absence of gestures, modulating self-involvement/being addressed; ACC effects tied to addressment ratings indicate self-relevance processing.
Involves perceiving others’ gestures and orientation and inferring communicative intent toward self vs other; taps action perception and mental-state understanding.
Interaction tests how gesture effects depend on egocentric vs allocentric context during addressment judgments; assesses social-cue integration within a social task.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation; gestures/orientation are communicative cues not bonding cues.
Directly examines context-dependent processing of co-speech gesture (non-facial communication) as a function of addressment orientation.
Findings/correlations indicate gesture-related addressment effects only in egocentric context (self-directed), implicating self-involvement in judging being addressed.
Requires interpreting others’ gestures/actions and communicative intent; gesture effect varies with whether message is directed to participant vs someone else.

This table only reports average peak Talairach coordinates for functionally localized face/body ROIs; it does not test any social contrast or measure social processing.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation or contrast is tested; coordinates table only.
No social communication (receptive/expressive) contrast is tested; coordinates table only.
No self-referential/agency/self-knowledge task or contrast; coordinates table only.
Although ROIs relate to perceiving faces/bodies, this table is not an analysis measuring perception/understanding of others; it only summarizes ROI locations from a localizer.
Contrast compares two types of person dyads differing in plausibility/meaningfulness of social interaction, which measures processing of social interaction information.
Dyads are not manipulating bonding/attachment, closeness, cooperation/competition, or relationship-specific affiliation; it is interaction congruency.
Task is sex categorization of dyads; contrast is interaction congruency rather than communication signals per se (e.g., facial/gaze/vocal communication reception/production).
No self-related judgments or agency; participants judge sex match of others.
Contrast probes perception/understanding of others' actions/relations (meaningful vs implausible interaction), fitting action perception/understanding others.
Incongruent vs congruent person interactions directly manipulates social interaction plausibility, a social processing contrast.
Not about attachment/bond strength or affiliation outcomes; only interaction congruency/meaningfulness.
Does not isolate communicative acts (e.g., gaze, facial expression decoding) as the measured construct; primary manipulation is dyad interaction congruency.
No self-referential component; viewing others.
Measures perception of others' actions/relations (implausible vs plausible interaction) aligning with action perception/understanding others.
Contrast compares congruent interactions to non-interactions (agents facing away), manipulating social interaction presence/meaningfulness; this measures social processing even if null.
No manipulation of bonding/attachment/affiliative relationship; interaction vs non-interaction is broader social perception.
Not specifically about communicative signal processing; it is interaction configuration (facing/related actions).
No self-processing demands.
Contrast targets perception of others in social relation (interacting vs not), consistent with action perception/understanding others.
Non-interactions vs congruent interactions contrasts different social-scene configurations (interaction absent vs present), qualifying as social processing.
Does not assess affiliative/attachment bonding; it is interaction configuration.
Not a communication-specific manipulation; focuses on whether dyad forms an interaction.
No self-referential processing.
Measures how observers perceive others' social relation (non-interaction vs interaction), fitting perception/understanding of others.
Incongruent interactions vs non-interactions compares two social-scene types differing in plausibility/interaction cues; this is a social-processing contrast.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation.
Not specifically assessing communication signal reception/production; manipulation is interaction congruency vs facing-away non-interaction.
No self-related judgments.
Assesses perception of others' actions/relations (implausible interaction vs non-interaction), within perception/understanding of others.
Non-interactions vs incongruent interactions contrasts two kinds of social dyad configurations; still measures social processing related to interaction interpretation.
Not about affiliative bonds or attachment.
Contrast does not isolate communicative exchange; it is dyad configuration/interaction plausibility.
No self-perception component.
Compares perception of others in different social relations (interaction absent vs implausible interaction), fitting perception/understanding of others.

Participants viewed videos of crowds of people expressing emotions (fear/happy/neutral), a socially relevant stimulus requiring perception of others' affect and actions; contrast examines differential response to fearful vs other crowd emotions, thus measuring social processing in the domain of perceiving others.

Task involves emotion/dynamics perception in crowds, not bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or close relationship evaluation; no affiliation/attachment construct is measured by the contrast.

Although stimuli depict emotional body expressions, the experiment does not require decoding communicative signals for interaction/communication per se (participants perform dot-color task) and the contrast is framed as emotion effects rather than communication exchange; does not directly measure social communication constructs as defined.
No self-referential judgment, agency, or self-knowledge task; contrast concerns perception of external crowd emotion.
Viewing fearful vs happy/neutral crowds indexes perception/understanding of others’ emotional states from body movement; fits action/animacy/emotion perception of others.

Contrast compares emotional (fear+happy) crowds to neutral crowds, probing neural response to socially relevant emotional body expressions in groups; this measures social processing broadly (emotion perception in others).
No manipulation or measurement of social bonds/attachment or affiliation behaviors; only emotional expression categories.

Stimuli are social and emotional but the analysis does not specifically target communicative exchange/reception tasks (e.g., explicit recognition/communication), and task is incidental dot detection; thus not a direct measure of social communication as defined.
No self-related processing component; participants are not evaluating themselves or their internal states.
Measures perception of others’ emotions (fear/happy) in crowds compared with neutral, fitting understanding of others’ affect/action cues.

Contrast isolates conditions (fear+neutral>happy) within viewing emotional crowds, reflecting differential processing of social/emotional crowd information; still within social processing domain of interpreting others’ affect/action cues.
Does not assess affiliation/attachment or social bonding; emotion category comparison only.
Not an explicit social-communication measure; focuses on emotional category differences during passive/implicit viewing with dot task.
No self-referential judgments or agency manipulation.
Compares neural responses while perceiving others’ emotional states in crowds (fear/neutral vs happy), thus measuring perception/understanding of others.
Happy>fear+neutral contrast during viewing crowds probes processing of socially relevant positive affect/body expression in others; part of social processing.
Happy crowd perception is not equivalent to affiliation/attachment measurement; no relationship/bonding evaluation.
No explicit communication decoding/production task; incidental dot detection while viewing; contrast not designed to test communicative exchange.
Does not involve self-awareness or self-judgment.
Indexes perception of others’ emotional state (happy) from dynamic crowds versus other emotions.
Neutral>fear+happy examines differences while observing social crowds expressing different affect; still measures processing of socially relevant human actions/expressions.
No affiliation/attachment construct; neutral vs emotional expressions only.
Not a direct social communication task/contrast; no communicative exchange or explicit interpretation required.
No self processing measured.
Even neutral crowds involve perception of others’ actions/states; contrast assesses differences in processing others across affective categories.

Main effect of dynamics (interactive>individual) directly manipulates social interaction within crowds; measuring processing of social interactions and group dynamics, a core aspect of social processing.
Interaction vs individual behavior is not specifically about bonding/attachment or affiliative relationship formation; lacks attachment/kinship/cooperation constructs.

Interactive vs individual crowds changes presence of communicative/interaction cues expressed through non-facial body movements; contrast targets processing of social interaction signals (receptive non-facial communication).
No self-related judgments or agency manipulation; participants observe others.
Contrast targets perception of others’ interactions/actions (interactive vs not), fitting action perception/understanding of others.
Interactive fear>individual fear contrasts panicked interactive crowd behavior vs noninteractive fear, directly probing social interaction processing under threat; measures social processing.
Fearful interaction/panic is not an affiliation/attachment manipulation; no bonding/relationship measure.
Difference is driven by interaction dynamics conveyed via body movements (non-facial communicative cues) within a crowd; thus measures receptive social communication signals.
No self-referential component; observation only.
Assesses perception/interpretation of others’ fearful actions and interactive dynamics (action perception/understanding mental states like panic).

Interaction effect component capturing stronger interactive vs individual differences in fear (and also happy) reflects processing of social interactions and emotional expressions in others; qualifies as social processing.
Includes happy interactions but does not assess attachment/affiliation bonding; no relationship context or measures.
Interactive>individual differences for fear and happy rely on interpreting interaction/communicative motion cues in crowds (receptive non-facial communication).
No self-knowledge/agency task.
Measures perception of others’ social interaction dynamics and affect across conditions.
Interactive fear>individual fear plus interactive neutral>individual neutral targets sensitivity to social interaction dynamics in crowds under fear and neutral affect; social processing.
No affiliation/attachment construct measured.
Manipulates presence of interaction cues (communicative body motion) vs independent behavior; receptive non-facial social communication.
No self-processing component.
Assesses action/interaction perception of others across conditions.

Interaction pattern (interactive fear>individual fear plus individual neutral>interactive neutral) still reflects differential processing of social interaction dynamics within emotional crowds; overall measures social processing of others.
Not related to bonding/attachment.
Contrasts conditions differing in interaction cues (interactive vs individual), which constitute non-facial communicative/social interaction information.
No self-referential processing required.
Measures perception of others’ interactions and emotional/action context.
Interactive neutral>individual neutral isolates effect of interaction dynamics independent of strong emotion; directly measures processing of social interaction cues in crowds.
Neutral interaction is not an attachment/affiliation measure; no bonding context.
Interactive vs individual neutral crowds differ in perceived social interaction/communicative cues via body motion; fits receptive non-facial social communication.
No self-focused evaluation.
Contrast measures perception of others’ interactive actions (action perception) even without emotion differences.

Task is an interactive sender–receiver (strategic communication) paradigm involving decisions to deceive vs tell the truth; contrast targets intention to deceive in social interaction, thus measuring social processing broadly.
Although interactive, the task is not designed to measure affiliation/attachment, bonding, closeness, or positive social ties; it focuses on deception/strategic manipulation for payoff.
Contrast is based on communicative acts (sending true/false messages) in a social exchange; it measures production of non-facial social communication (messaging) under deceptive vs truthful intent.
Contrast does not primarily probe self-referential judgment, agency attribution, or self-knowledge; it compares deception vs truth in interaction, mainly other-directed strategic reasoning.

Deception (simple+sophisticated) requires modeling the receiver’s beliefs/expectations (theory of mind). The contrast explicitly indexes intention to deceive by anticipating the receiver’s mental state.
Interactive deception decision in a sender–receiver game; simple deception vs truth isolates social deception processes within a social interaction context.
No manipulation/measure of attachment, bonding, or affiliative/cooperative relationship formation; incentives are monetary and competitive/strategic rather than affiliative.
Contrast compares sending a false message vs truthful message to another person—i.e., production of socially relevant (non-facial) communication in an interaction.
Not a self-reflection/self-knowledge task; although involves internal conflict, the measured construct is not self-perception but communicative deception.

Successful lying in this strategic context entails reasoning about the receiver’s likely beliefs/choices; thus it measures understanding others’ mental states even if less explicit than sophisticated deception.
Sophisticated deception (truthful message with intent to mislead) is inherently social/interactive and depends on strategic social cognition; contrast vs truth measures social processing.
Does not assess affiliative bonding/attachment; it assesses deceptive strategy for payoff.
Operationalized via communicative messaging to another agent; contrast tests deceptive intent while communicating (non-facial production).
No explicit self-referential judgments; main demand is strategic other-related inference rather than self-knowledge/agency attribution.

Definition of sophisticated deception explicitly depends on the sender’s expectation about the receiver’s belief (ToM/mentalizing); contrast isolates such other-mental-state reasoning vs genuine truth.
Both conditions are social deception modes within an interactive game; contrasting sophisticated vs simple deception probes differences in social-cognitive demands in interaction.
Contrast does not involve affiliative/attachment processes; it compares two deception strategies.
Both involve producing communicative messages; contrast examines how communication strategy (truthful vs false message under deceptive intent) modulates neural activity.
Not centered on self-evaluation or self-referential cognition; differences are attributed to ToM/strategic reasoning rather than self-perception constructs.
Sophisticated deception requires heightened inference about the receiver’s beliefs/expectations compared with simple deception; thus the contrast targets understanding others’ mental states.
Truth-telling vs deception in a social interaction context still measures social processing because it concerns communicative choices affecting another person in a strategic game.
Although 'truth' could be prosocial, this contrast is not an attachment/affiliation manipulation (no relationship cues, bonding, or closeness measures).
Contrast compares communicative acts (truthful communication with expectation of being believed) against deceptive communication; this is squarely within social communication.
Not a self-referential judgment/agency task; activation for 'genuine truth' is interpreted in reward/control terms, but the contrast itself is not designed to measure self-perception.

Genuine truth trials require expecting the receiver will believe/follow the message; deception conditions require manipulating that expectation—both hinge on modeling the other's likely choice/belief.

Parametric modulation of conflict during deception in a strategic sender–receiver setting assesses how social interaction incentives (tension between players’ payoffs) modulate deception-related processing.
Parametric regressor indexes payoff conflict/tension, not attachment, bonding, or affiliative relationship processes.
Modulates neural responses during deceptive message sending as a function of incentive/conflict; still within communicative exchange in an interaction.
The parametric effect reflects incentive/conflict during deception rather than self-knowledge or self-referential evaluation per se.

Even though modulator is payoff tension, trials are deception in interaction and require anticipating receiver’s response; thus it still measures other-directed mental-state reasoning within the deception context.

Task involves predicting others' behavior from rules/desires (social inference/impression updating). Contrast averages rules+desires during portrait events, capturing social processing engaged by person perception and inference.
No manipulation of bonding/attachment, close relationships, cooperation, or affiliation; targets are unknown characters and judgments are about compliance/desires.
Although faces/text are presented, the contrast is not about communicative signal reception/production (e.g., gaze, emotion recognition); it's about behavior prediction/impression learning.
No self-referential judgments or self-knowledge/agency manipulation; focus is on others.
Portrait-event processing requires representing/learning others' behavioral tendencies in rule/desire contexts (understanding others' traits/mental-state-related behavior).
Conjunction of (Rules>0) and (Desires>0) for portraits isolates common social inference/person impression components across both scenarios.
No attachment/affiliation construct assessed in this conjunction; still about unknown others and predictions.
Not targeted at communicative cue processing; rather general person inference common to both conditions.
No self processing component in this contrast.
Common activation reflects perceiving portraits and reasoning about others' likely actions (others-focused representations).
Desires>Rules isolates differential social-cognitive processing when predicting behavior from stated desires (mentalizing-like inference).
Does not involve affiliation/attachment or bonding; it's a mental state vs rule framing contrast.
Not a communicative exchange/recognition contrast; focuses on inference about motivations.
No self-referential processing contrasted.
Specifically targets understanding others' desires as determinants of action (understanding mental states/traits of others).
Rules>Desires tests differential social inference when behavior is framed as compliance with external rules (deontic social reasoning).
No attachment, bonding, or affiliation manipulation; deontic compliance is not affiliation/attachment per se.
Not about decoding communicative facial/nonfacial signals; it contrasts rule vs desire framing for prediction.
No self-perception component.
Requires representing others' tendencies to obey/violate rules (others' traits/behavioral dispositions).
Feedback-event contrast (0 > Rules+Desires) reflects task-related changes during social learning about others; still within social inference context (processing outcomes of others' behavior).
Feedback processing does not index affiliation/attachment; no relationship/bond manipulation.
Feedback images are not communicative cues being decoded for communication; contrast is about general feedback-related activity decreases.
Not self-focused; feedback pertains to others' actions/consistency and participant accuracy.
Feedback depicts the person performing (or not) the activity, informing learning about others' behavioral profiles.
Desires>Rules for feedback events contrasts social learning signals when outcomes are framed by desires vs rules, within an interpersonal inference task.
No affiliation/attachment construct; simply outcome feedback under different framings.
Not about communicative interaction; it is about outcome evaluation/learning about others.
Does not involve self-knowledge or self-judgment manipulation.
Feedback provides information about others' action tendencies linked to desires; contrast indexes differential processing of others-related outcomes.
Last-two-bins portrait contrast (Rules+Desires)/2 > Neutral isolates social framing effects (mental state/rule contexts) during accurate person prediction—core social processing.
Not about social bonds/attachment; compares social framing to neutral descriptions.
Involves faces/text but not communication-specific processing; neutral vs rule/desire framing for inference.
No self-referential component.
Targets understanding others under desire/rule contexts versus neutral, i.e., richer representations of others' motivations/constraints.
Conjunction (Rules>Neutral) ∩ (Desires>Neutral) in late learning captures shared social inference components beyond neutral descriptions.
No attachment/affiliation processes measured by this conjunction.
Not focused on communicative cue decoding; shared effects relate to prediction/inference about others.
No self processing contrasted.
Common activation reflects understanding others' behavior under socially meaningful framings (rules/desires).
Neutral > (Rules+Desires)/2 primarily indexes reduced social framing/mentalizing/deontic content (more nonsocial contextual description). It is not measuring increased social processing.
No affiliation/attachment content.
Not a communication-related contrast; neutral context dominates.
No self processing.
Contrast emphasizes neutral framing over social rule/desire inference; does not measure increased reasoning about others' traits/mental states.
Late (last two bins) Desires>Rules isolates mental-state based prediction when participants have learned profiles; clear social-cognitive processing difference.
No bonding/attachment construct.
Not communication per se; compares inference under desires vs rules.
No self-referential element.
Directly about understanding others' desires guiding actions (understanding mental states of others).
Late Rules>Desires targets deontic social inference (obedience/violation tendencies) relative to desire inference.
No affiliative/attachment manipulation.
Not focused on communicative signals; it is about rule-based behavior prediction.
No self processing.
Represents others' compliance with rules (traits/behavioral dispositions of others).
SCENARIO×PROFILE interaction contrasts predicting violating vs compliant characters (in late learning), engaging impression updating/evaluation of others' norm/desire violations—social processing.
Although trustworthiness is related, task does not assess affiliative bonding or attachment relationships; it's norm/desire violation prediction.
No communication exchange; focuses on trait-like evaluation/prediction.
Not self-related.
Specifically about representing others' propensity to violate expectations (trait inference/understanding others' behavioral dispositions).
Opposite SCENARIO×PROFILE interaction (predicting compliant vs violating, depending on framing) remains within social inference about others' behavior.
No attachment/affiliation processes manipulated; contrast is about expectation consistency profiles.
Not communication-related; involves attention/oculomotor regions (FEF) but driven by social prediction context, not communicative cues.
No self processing.
Still concerns predicting others' behavior based on learned profiles (others-focused reasoning).

Exogenous system (Ω+) is derived from a dyadic eye-contact social interaction paradigm and is interpreted as reciprocity-related processing (empathy/mirror, social interaction). This measures social processing broadly.

Task involves eye contact/open-close synchronization, not bonding/attachment, relationship evaluation, cooperation/competition, or loved-one related contrasts; no affiliation/attachment construct is directly measured.
Eye contact is a core component of facial social communication; Ω+ specifically targets reciprocal responses during mutual gaze, aligning with receptive/interactive facial communication.

Although framed theoretically with interoception/exteroception, Ω+ is exogenous reciprocal response to seeing partner’s eyes, not self-referential judgments, agency, or explicit self-monitoring task/contrast.

Mutual gaze requires perceiving another person’s eyes/face and social cues; Ω+ is defined as response to reciprocal exteroceptive stimulus of seeing partner’s eyes, thus involving perception/understanding of others.
Endogenous system (Ω−) is derived from reciprocal interaction during eye contact and interpreted as mentalization/DMN emergence in social interaction, clearly within social processing.
No manipulation/contrast of attachment, closeness, loved one vs stranger, or affiliative behavior; endogenous activations are tied to reciprocal interaction/mentalization rather than bonding.
Ω− reflects endogenous processes engaged during reciprocal eye contact interaction, supporting interactive social communication (coordination/reciprocity) rather than mere non-social introspection.

Despite discussion of interoceptive/endogenous and default-mode, the task/contrast is not self-judgment, explicit self-knowledge, or agency; Ω− is interpreted primarily as mentalization/reciprocal interaction mechanisms.
Ω− is interpreted as mentalization network activation during reciprocal interaction (understanding others’ mental states) prompted by mutual gaze, fitting perception/understanding of others.

Task requires making attributions about social stimuli (emotional expressions and intentional actions) contrasted with factual judgments (why>how); conjunction across stimulus categories includes social conditions and measures attributional processing relevant to social cognition.

Although social stimuli are present, the contrast isolates attributional (why) vs factual (how) reasoning rather than bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship processing.

Stimuli include faces and actions, but the contrast targets causal/mental-state attribution (why>how) rather than communicative signal reception/production (e.g., facial identity/affect recognition as primary aim, gaze, turn-taking).
No self-referential judgments or self-trait/state evaluation; participants judge photos/questions about others or nonsocial scenes.

Why>how for social stimuli involves inferring others' mental states/motives/emotions (theory of mind/understanding mental states). Even though conjunction includes nonsocial scenes too, the task and contrast encompass explicit mental-state attribution for people.
Interaction contrast identifies regions more engaged by attributional processing for social (emotions/actions) than nonsocial scenes, directly measuring social-selective attribution/mentalizing.
Social>nonsocial selectivity is driven by mental-state attribution, not affiliative bonding/attachment or relationship-focused evaluation.
Contrast does not isolate communicative exchange or decoding/production of communicative signals as the primary construct; it isolates why>how attributional reasoning differences by domain.
No self-focused processing or self-knowledge/agency judgments are required or contrasted.
Social-selective why>how effect reflects stronger inference about others' unobservable mental states underlying behavior (understanding mental states).

Task involves processing socially relevant face cues (emotion, in-/out-group) while regulating imitation; contrast indexes mimicry regulation within a social context and engages social-cognitive control (e.g., TPJ).

Although study motivation is affiliative, this specific contrast (Incongruent>Congruent collapsed across social conditions) indexes general imitation inhibition/conflict rather than affiliation/attachment per se; no explicit bond/relationship or affiliative outcome is contrasted here.

Contrast does not isolate reception/production of communicative signals; it collapses across emotion/group and primarily measures motor conflict/imitation control rather than facial communication processing.

Imitation inhibition requires self-other action control/agency (distinguishing own intended action from observed action), a core self-related monitoring component reflected in this incongruent>congruent regulation contrast.
Participants observe others' finger movements and faces; regulation relies on processing observed actions (action perception) to resolve conflict between observed and executed movement.
Contrast specifically targets mimicry regulation modulated by happy (affiliative) facial expressions, directly measuring processing of social-emotional cues during action control.
Happy faces are treated as affiliative signals and the contrast isolates mimicry regulation in response to these affiliation-relevant cues (happy>angry modulation of incongruent>congruent).
Uses facial emotional expressions (receptive facial communication) as the key manipulation; contrast measures how processing of these communicative cues modulates imitation control.
Mimicry regulation in happy context engages self-other distinction/agency (e.g., rTPJ) to maintain one's intended action in the presence of affiliative cues.
Happy expression is an others' affective state cue; contrast measures neural response to others' emotional expressions influencing action perception and control.
Contrast isolates mimicry regulation specifically in the angry-face context (angry>happy modulation), involving processing of socially relevant threat/negative affect cues.
Angry faces are non-affiliative signals; while they may influence social interaction, this contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment or bonding processes.
Manipulation is facial emotional expression (reception of facial communication); contrast captures how angry communicative cues modulate imitation control.
Still an imitation-inhibition contrast requiring self-other action control/agency in an angry social context.
Requires perception of others' angry facial affect and observed action to compute incongruency and regulate responses.
Contrast targets mimicry regulation specifically modulated by out-group membership (out-group>in-group modulation), directly measuring social group processing effects on action control.
Out-group manipulation is interpreted as eliciting affiliative/appeasement motives; contrast isolates neural regulation of mimicry in response to group membership relevant to affiliation goals.
Group membership is conveyed via faces (social signal) and modulates interpersonal signaling via mimicry; contrast captures processing of these socially communicative cues affecting behavior.
Regulating one’s own responses under out-group context involves self-monitoring/agency and control of automatic imitation tendencies.
Requires categorizing others as out-group and processing their observed actions; directly engages representations about others (social categorization/action perception).
Contrast targets mimicry regulation specifically modulated by in-group membership (in-group>out-group modulation), measuring social group processing effects on imitation control.
In-group cues are directly related to social bonding/affiliation; contrast isolates regulation of mimicry as a putative affiliative signal toward in-group vs out-group.
Group membership communicated via faces; contrast captures differential processing of this social signal impacting interpersonal mimicry regulation.
Imitation control in the in-group condition still requires self-other distinction/agency and self-related action monitoring.
Involves representing the other as an in-group member and processing their observed action cues while regulating imitation.

Contrast compares observed eye contact vs observed averted gaze between two faces, a paradigmatic social cue-processing manipulation; measures neural response to social information (attentional relation between others).

Although eye contact can relate to affiliation, this task does not assess bonding/attachment, close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition, or affiliative preference; it manipulates gaze direction for attentional cueing rather than attachment-related constructs.
Eye contact is a core facial communicative signal; this contrast isolates processing of observed eye contact versus non-eye-contact, aligning with receptive facial communication cues.
No self-referential judgments, agency, or self-knowledge components; participants respond to target identity, not self states/traits.
Participants perceive and interpret others' gaze/attentional relation (two agents looking at each other vs away), fitting action/animacy perception and inference about others' attention.

Contrast compares observed averted gaze vs observed eye contact between two faces; still a social-cue manipulation and measures neural response to social information conveyed by gaze/attentional relation.
Does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no relationship context, bonding, loved-one stimuli, or attachment measures); primarily attentional/social cue processing.
Averted vs mutual gaze is part of facial communication signaling communicative engagement/disengagement; contrast captures receptive processing of these facial communicative cues.
No self-focused processing required by task/contrast.
Requires perception/interpretation of others' gaze directions and their relation to each other (attentional relation absent vs present).
Contrast compares congruent vs incongruent gaze cues in a gaze-following paradigm with faces; measures processing of socially derived attentional cues (others' gaze) and resulting social attention.
Gaze cueing is not an assessment of attachment/affiliation or bonding; no relationship-based manipulation.
Gaze following uses gaze direction as a nonverbal communicative cue; congruent vs incongruent indexes receptive processing of gaze signals guiding attention.
Contrast does not involve self-evaluation, self-knowledge, or agency; it's about external gaze cues guiding attention to targets.
Participants interpret others' gaze direction relative to target (action perception/understanding others' attentional focus).
Incongruent vs congruent gaze cues in gaze-following paradigm probes social attention mechanisms driven by others' gaze and violation of expected attentional cueing.
No affiliation/attachment construct is manipulated or measured; incongruency reflects attentional reorienting, not bonding.
Indexes processing of gaze as a communicative/attentional cue (nonverbal communication) when it mismatches target location.
Not self-referential; task remains other-cue driven attention.
Requires representing others' gaze direction/attentional focus and detecting mismatch with target (action perception of others' attention).

Interaction-related contrast comparing congruent gaze trials after observed eye contact vs after observed averted gaze; directly measures how social context (others' mutual eye contact) modulates gaze-following processing.
Although mutual eye contact can be affiliative, this contrast targets modulation of attention by observed eye contact rather than attachment/bond formation or relationship valuation.
Assesses communicative value of eye contact as an ostensive cue modulating subsequent gaze cue processing; squarely within receptive facial communication/gaze following.
No self-related appraisal; effect concerns processing of others' communicative/attentional signals.
Involves perceiving an attentional relation between two others and using it to interpret their subsequent gaze toward an object (understanding others' attention/intentional relation).
Within averted-gaze context, contrast compares incongruent vs congruent gaze cues, assessing social attention/gaze-following costs when others' gaze cues mismatch target.
No affiliative/attachment manipulation beyond attentional relation; this contrast focuses on attentional congruency effects, not bonding or relationship constructs.
Gaze direction provides nonverbal communicative information; incongruent vs congruent within averted context measures processing of this communicative cue under a specific prior social signal.
No self-perception component; participants' self is not evaluated.
Requires representing others' gaze and detecting mismatch with target location (others' attentional focus/action perception).

This interaction contrast includes an emotional face gender-identification condition (angry faces) compared against a non-social shape control, and tests how temporal structure modulates processing differences between social (faces) vs non-social stimuli. Because faces are inherently social stimuli and the task requires processing information from human faces (others), the contrast measures social processing differences (though framed as timing-by-stimulus interaction).

No manipulation or measurement of bonding, attachment, kinship, closeness, cooperation/competition, or relationship-specific targets; angry faces vs shapes with timing manipulation is not an affiliation/attachment construct.

The task involves perception of facial cues (gender identification on angry faces) which falls under receptive facial communication/face processing. The interaction contrast assesses neural responses when processing facial social signals (faces) relative to non-social shapes under different timing, thus measuring a social-communication relevant component (reception of facial information).
No self-referential judgment, self-trait evaluation, agency, or self-monitoring task; stimuli and contrasts pertain to processing external faces/shapes and timing.

Participants perceive and categorize attributes of other people (gender from angry faces). This is perception/understanding of others (a feature of another person) contrasted against non-social control within a timing interaction, so it measures processing of others-related information.

This interaction contrast includes a happy face gender-identification condition relative to a non-social shape control and tests how temporal structure modulates processing of social (faces) vs non-social stimuli. Because it involves processing socially relevant facial stimuli (others), it falls within social processing.

Happy faces here are not relationship-specific, bonding/attachment related, or measuring social affiliation (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation); it is a perceptual gender-decision task with timing manipulation.

The task requires receptive processing of facial information (gender identification) from happy faces, which is within social communication (reception of facial communication). The interaction evaluates how timing affects face vs non-face processing.
No self-related processing (agency/self-knowledge) is manipulated or contrasted; the task concerns external face/shapes under timing manipulation.

Participants process attributes of others from facial stimuli (gender from happy faces). This targets perception/understanding of others rather than self, and the contrast tests timing-dependent differences relative to non-social stimuli.

Task involves receiving social reputation feedback from others (faces + evaluative statements) and rating pleasantness; contrast Positive vs Neutral isolates processing of positive social evaluation, a social processing construct.

Although stimuli are socially evaluative, the task does not measure bonding/attachment, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or affiliation formation; it is reputation/valence processing from strangers.

Participants process communicative social feedback (verbal comments attributed to a person) paired with faces; Positive vs Neutral captures reception/interpretation of socially relevant communication.
Comments are directed at 'You are ...' requiring self-referential appraisal/affective response to feedback about self; Positive vs Neutral indexes self-related evaluation.
Stimuli include faces (male/female) as sources of evaluation; processing involves representing another agent as giver of feedback, engaging perception/understanding of others in a minimal form.
Negative vs Neutral contrasts processing of negative social reputation feedback from others during a social evaluation task, clearly within social processing.
No manipulation of attachment/affiliation bonds; reputational statements from unfamiliar faces do not operationalize affiliation/attachment.
Negative evaluative comments are socially communicated information; contrast targets reception/interpretation of social-verbal communication relative to neutral instruction trials.
Derogatory/negative self-directed feedback ('You are ...') engages self-referential processing and evaluation of self-relevant social information.
Feedback is attributed to another person (face) requiring representation of an external evaluator; thus involves perception of others alongside self-relevance.
Conjunction identifies regions commonly activated by positive and negative social reputation feedback (both > neutral), directly measuring social processing during social evaluation.
Common activation for reputational feedback is not specific to affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding, relationship closeness, or cooperation).
Both positive and negative conditions involve reception of socially meaningful verbal messages from a depicted person; conjunction captures general social communication processing.
Both valences are self-referential evaluations; conjunction indexes valence-independent self-related processing of reputation (e.g., self-referential appraisal/arousal).
Both conditions include an evaluator (face) and require attribution of comments to others; conjunction reflects general processing of others as social agents.
(Positive>Neutral) vs (Negative>Neutral) isolates brain regions specifically more engaged by positive social reputation than negative, within a social evaluation task.
Valence-specific reputation processing (positive vs negative) is not an affiliation/attachment manipulation and does not probe bonding/relationship formation.
Contrast compares two types of socially communicated feedback (positive vs negative) controlling for neutral; measures differential processing of social communication valence.
Differential responses to positive vs negative self-relevant evaluations directly reflect self-referential valuation/affective appraisal.

Because feedback is delivered by male/female faces, the contrast still involves representing another person as evaluator; however primary emphasis is on self-relevant valence—still qualifies as others-present social processing.
(Negative>Neutral) vs (Positive>Neutral) would identify regions specifically more engaged by negative social reputation than positive, within a social evaluation paradigm.
Negative-specific reputation processing is not an affiliation/attachment construct (no close bonds/cooperation/attachment measures).
Compares processing of negative vs positive socially communicated feedback while controlling for neutral; indexes valence-dependent aspects of social communication reception.
Negative vs positive feedback about self taps self-evaluative processing and affective self-relevance differences.
Feedback is attributed to another person (face) and thus entails representing others as sources of evaluation, even though the contrast targets valence specificity.

EmpaToM contrast compares emotionally negative vs neutral autobiographical social videos designed to induce empathic responding; this is a social cognition manipulation within a social task.
Contrast manipulates emotionality/empathy for strangers in videos, not affiliative bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-specific processing.

Although stimuli are communicative narratives, the contrast tests emotional empathy (negative vs neutral) rather than communicative cue reception/production (e.g., facial/gestural/gaze communication) as the target construct.
Participants rate their own affective state after each video; the negative>neutral manipulation targets changes in one's own experienced affect (self-state awareness) elicited by social stimuli.
Empathy condition requires perceiving/representing the other person's emotional suffering conveyed in the videos; negative>neutral indexes processing of others' affective states.
ToM>nonToM questions require inferring others' thoughts/intentions vs factual reasoning about the same social narratives; clear social-cognitive manipulation.
Mentalizing about a narrator's beliefs/intentions is not an affiliation/attachment manipulation (no bonding, closeness, cooperation, or loved-one processing).
Questions test Theory of Mind reasoning rather than decoding/producing social communicative signals (faces, gaze, prosody, gestures) as the primary construct.
Primary contrast concerns reasoning about others' mental states vs factual reasoning; no self-referential judgment/agency manipulation defines the contrast.
Theory of Mind questions directly require understanding others' mental states (beliefs, goals, intentions) relative to factual control questions.
Same EmpaToM empathy contrast in large sample: emotionally negative vs neutral social narratives to elicit empathic responding; social processing is central.
No manipulation of attachment/affiliation (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding/cooperation); it's empathy to actors/narrators.
Assesses affect sharing/empathy rather than specific social communication reception/production processes as the construct of interest.
Includes self-focused affect ratings and indexes changes in participants' own internal emotional state due to social stimuli (negative>neutral).
Requires perception/representation of others' emotional states depicted in videos; negative content increases empathic processing of others.
EmpaToM ToM>nonToM questions contrast indexes mentalizing during social narratives, a core social-cognition process.
Contrast is not about social bonding/attachment/affiliation; it is about inferring mental states vs factual reasoning.
Targets Theory of Mind reasoning, not communication cue decoding/production per se.
No explicit self-knowledge/agency judgment contrast; the manipulation is other-focused mental-state inference vs factual control.
Directly measures understanding others' mental states (ToM) contrasted with non-mental-state factual reasoning.
Differential contrast compares empathy-related processing to ToM-related processing within a social task; both are social cognition, so the contrast still measures social processing differences.
Neither side of the contrast manipulates attachment/affiliation; it contrasts empathy vs ToM demands.
Contrast dissociates empathy vs ToM networks, not social communication reception/production specifically.
Empathy>ToM emphasizes affect sharing with corresponding self-affective experience (valence), which includes self-state processing relative to ToM reasoning.
Empathy component involves representing others' emotional states more than ToM questions baseline; still fundamentally about understanding others.
Differential contrast ToM>Empathy isolates mentalizing-specific processing relative to empathic affect sharing within the same social task; both are social processing domains.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation; it contrasts ToM reasoning with empathic processing.
This contrast is about understanding mental states (ToM) vs empathy, not communicative signal processing.
ToM>Empathy is primarily other-mental-state inference; it does not target self-knowledge/agency processes as defined by the construct.
ToM>Empathy explicitly emphasizes understanding others' mental states (beliefs/intentions) over affect sharing, fitting 'understanding mental states' of others.

Task involves gaze-following to socially meaningful stimuli (political personage faces) and contrasts (e.g., incongruent>congruent; in-group vs out-group) index processing of social cues (gaze, group membership) and their modulation of attention/control, thus measuring social processing broadly.

Although in-group vs out-group political affiliation is manipulated, the task measures attentional interference/gaze following rather than affiliation/attachment bonding or relationship formation (e.g., loved one/close other, cooperation/competition, attachment constructs).

Gaze shifts are core nonverbal communicative signals; the gaze-following/interference contrast measures receptive processing of social gaze (social communication) even though participants are not interacting with a live agent.

Self-related measures (SDO, perceived similarity) are collected as individual-difference moderators, but the fMRI contrasts themselves are not self-referential judgment/agency tasks; they are attention/gaze-following to others' faces.

Participants perceive and interpret others' social signals (directional gaze) and social category (in-group/out-group politicians); contrasts reflect processing of others' actions/traits relevance rather than self-judgment.

The contrast ToM > Random uses a theory-of-mind (mentalizing) social task (animated triangles depicting intentional interactions vs random motion), directly measuring social cognitive processing.
The task targets attribution of intentions/mental states (ToM) rather than forming/assessing social bonds, attachment, cooperation/competition, or affiliative valuation.
No communicative exchange (facial/non-facial reception/production) is required; participants passively view animations and mentalize. This is not a social communication paradigm.
The contrast does not involve self-referential judgments, agency over actions, or self-knowledge; it focuses on interpreting others’ intentions.
Theory of Mind requires reasoning about others’ mental states/intentions; ToM > Random specifically isolates mental-state attribution to the animated agents.

This Bayesian VOI analysis evaluates whether ToM > Random elicits activation in mPFC, a key ToM network node, thus still assessing neural response during a social (mentalizing) task condition contrast.
The VOI analysis concerns ToM-related activation differences, not affiliative bonding/attachment constructs.
The VOI analysis is based on mentalizing (ToM) vs random motion, not communication reception/production processes.
The mPFC VOI is tested in the context of ToM > Random; the task does not require explicit self-referential or agency judgments, so it is not a self-perception construct analysis.
The VOI test pertains to ToM processing (understanding others’ intentions/mental states) as elicited by ToM > Random, even though the result supports the null in mPFC.
This Bayesian VOI analysis in right posterior superior temporal gyrus evaluates ToM > Random responses, part of the ToM network, and thus measures social processing during a mentalizing contrast.
The VOI analysis is not about affiliation/attachment or bonding-related evaluation.
No communicative exchange is measured; the analysis is about ToM-related activation in STG/TPJ area during ToM vs random animations.
The analysis does not require self-related appraisal or agency; it targets responses linked to interpreting others’ behavior/mental states.
Right posterior STG/TPJ involvement here indexes understanding of others’ intentions/mental states in the ToM > Random contrast, fitting perception/understanding of others.

Main effect of pain (painful vs neutral images) during an empathy-for-pain task; participants explicitly empathize with depicted individuals, engaging social processing broadly (empathy/other-related affect).

Contrast is pain vs neutral regardless of ingroup/outgroup bonding/relationship; does not specifically index affiliation/attachment processes (no loved-one/attachment/cooperation manipulation in this contrast).
Stimuli are images of hands/feet in situations; task is empathic pain rating rather than decoding/producing communicative signals (faces, gaze, gestures) or exchanging social information.
Participants make ratings but contrast is not self-referential judgment or introspective self-knowledge/agency; it targets responses to others' pain vs neutral.
Empathy-for-pain requires assessing others’ affective state (perceived pain) from images; pain vs neutral directly manipulates perceived state of the other.
Main effect of condition (ingroup vs outgroup) during empathy-for-pain paradigm; explicitly social categorization/group membership influences processing.
Ingroup vs outgroup manipulation operationalizes affiliation/group membership bias (minimal group), a core aspect of social affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Although group labels are shown, the contrast is not about communicative signal reception/production; it reflects group membership processing rather than social communication per se.
Does not require explicit self-evaluation or self-referential judgments; focuses on others categorized as ingroup/outgroup.
Ingroup/outgroup categorization concerns representations of others’ social identity; participants evaluate others (targets) as belonging to groups, which is other-perception.
Main effect of gender (male vs female participants) within an empathy-for-pain task reflects differences in neural processing during a social/empathic paradigm, thus measuring social processing.
Gender main effect is a between-subject factor and does not itself constitute an affiliation/attachment manipulation or bond-related contrast.
No communication signal processing contrast; gender differences are not specifically tied to receptive/expressive communication components.
Between-subject gender differences are not self-perception contrasts; no explicit self-knowledge/agency task component isolated by this contrast.
Even though moderator is participant gender, the task remains judging others' pain; thus the neural effect pertains to processing others’ states during empathy.
Pain×condition interaction tests ingroup bias in empathy for pain (others’ pain) as a function of group membership—central social processing (empathy modulated by social group).
Interaction explicitly captures differential empathic responding to ingroup vs outgroup suffering, indexing affiliation/group-bond modulation of empathic processing.
Not about decoding communicative acts; it is affective empathy and group categorization rather than social communication reception/production.
No explicit self-referential processing; interaction concerns responses to others’ pain depending on others’ group membership.
Requires evaluating others’ pain and integrates social identity information (ingroup/outgroup) about the target; directly about representations of others’ emotional states.
Pain×gender interaction occurs within an empathy-for-pain paradigm; it reflects modulation of social/empathic processing by participant gender.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation; gender moderator does not operationalize bonding or group affiliation contrast.
Interaction is not about communicative exchange or signal processing; it is about empathic response to pain stimuli across genders.
Does not isolate self-focused evaluation/agency; gender interaction modulates responses to others' pain vs neutral.
The underlying contrast (pain vs neutral) is about perceiving and evaluating others’ pain; gender moderates this other-perception/empathy process.

Contrast isolates brain activity for explicitly judging whether stimuli relate to the self (self-referential/non-social > social/non-self-referential). This is a social-cognitive/self-related judgment task component, thus measures social processing broadly (self/other related processing within social cognition domain).

No manipulation or measurement of bonding, attachment, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or affiliative motivation; stimuli are IAPS pictures categorized by social content and self-referentiality.
Task does not involve producing or interpreting communicative signals (e.g., facial affect recognition, gaze, communicative intent); it is a self-relatedness judgment and passive viewing.

Directly contrasts conditions to isolate self-referential processing (explicit self-relatedness judgment) relative to social/other-focused processing, matching self-knowledge/self-referential perception construct.

Although the comparator condition includes social pictures, this contrast is designed to highlight self-referential processing rather than perception/understanding of others; it subtracts social/non-self from self/non-social.

Contrast isolates implicit social stimulus processing (social/non-self-referential > self-referential/non-social) based on viewing pictures with humans vs non-social images, thus measures social processing.
No affiliative/attachment manipulation (no loved one, bonding, cooperation/competition, relationship evaluation).

While social pictures may include faces/bodies, the contrast is not a communication task (no explicit facial emotion/identity recognition, gaze following, or communicative exchange). It targets social content/animacy more generally.
This contrast emphasizes social stimulus processing over self-referential processing, not self-knowledge/agency.

Social stimuli are defined by presence of humans and the contrast (social/non-self > self/non-social) isolates processing of others/animacy and person perception (TPJ, pSTS/EBA, FFA), aligning with perception/understanding of others (animacy/action perception).

Passive viewing of in-/out-group faces with disgust vs neutral targets social information processing (race group membership and facial emotion). The interaction contrast isolates racially biased disgust perception, a core social-perceptual process.

The task involves perceiving facial expressions by racial group, not forming/maintaining social bonds, attachment, cooperation/competition, or relationship evaluation. No affiliation/attachment construct is directly manipulated in the contrast.

Faces conveying disgust are communicative social signals; the contrast tests differential neural response to reception of facial affect communication for out-group vs in-group (interaction removing neutral baseline).

No self-referential judgments, self-trait/state evaluation, agency, or self-knowledge processing is required; participants passively view faces and the contrast reflects perception of others rather than self-processing.
The contrast measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states (disgust) and group membership (in/out-group), i.e., social perception of others’ affect with racial bias.
Task-dependent (gPPI) connectivity during racially biased disgust perception indexes social information processing networks engaged by viewing out-/in-group disgust faces.
Connectivity reflects affective salience/regulation during out-group disgust perception, not attachment bonding, affiliation, cooperation, or close relationship processing.
The psychological context is reception of facial affect (disgust) from others with race modulation; connectivity (insula–amygdala, etc.) reflects processing of communicative facial signals.
No self-referential component is modeled; PPI context and seed reflect processing of externally presented faces rather than self-knowledge/agency.
Connectivity during the out-group bias in disgust perception pertains to representing others’ emotional expressions and socially relevant category (race), i.e., perception/understanding of others.

Negative task-dependent connectivity (e.g., insula–ACC) during racially biased disgust perception reflects social processing, particularly affective evaluation/regulation elicited by others’ faces differing by group.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation; negative coupling relates to regulatory control during perception of out-group disgust, not social bonding.

The modulation of connectivity is tied to receiving facial emotional communication (disgust) from out-group vs in-group targets; ACC coupling reflects regulation in response to communicative social cues.
The analysis does not involve self-focused appraisal or self-related judgments; it is driven by processing of others’ faces.
Negative coupling patterns are elicited in the context of evaluating others’ disgust expressions with racial group modulation, fitting perception/understanding of others’ affective states.
