Task context includes social competition condition (belief of competing against another person) integrated across study; working-memory maintenance phase occurs within this social vs non-social manipulation, but this specific analysis is overall working memory maintenance effects (including deactivation in mPFC/PCC) and notes no condition differences. Still, participants are in a socially framed task in part, so broad social-processing applies at task level, though contrast not explicitly social. Include under broad umbrella.

Working memory maintenance analysis is not a contrast isolating competition vs noncompetition and does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment or social bonding; it reflects general task engagement/deactivation related to performance.
No communicative signal processing (faces, gestures, speech) is manipulated or contrasted in this analysis; it is cognitive working memory maintenance.

Although midline DMN regions relate to self-referential thought, this analysis measures performance-related deactivation during working memory maintenance without an explicit self-judgment or self-referential task/contrast.
No explicit reasoning about others is required/contrasted in this working memory maintenance analysis (and no competition vs no-competition effect reported).
This analysis is the effect of performance parametric modulator within the no-competition condition (non-social). It measures general working memory performance effects, not social processing.
No social interaction/competition present in this condition; does not measure affiliation/attachment.
No communication-related stimuli or contrasts; purely cognitive performance modulation in non-social context.
Not an explicit self-referential judgment; parametric modulation by accuracy in a nonsocial task.
No representation of others in no-competition condition; not measuring understanding of others.

Performance parametric modulation within the competition condition involves a socially competitive context (opponent present, social comparison). Even though modulation is by task performance, it occurs under social manipulation relevant to social processing.

Competition is explicitly an affiliation/attachment-relevant social interaction construct per examples (cooperation and competition; social comparison). This analysis examines performance-related neural effects while competing, thus measuring a component of competitive social context.
Competition here is conveyed via feedback numbers; not a communication-perception task (no facial/nonfacial communicative cues as primary manipulation).

Competing and receiving/using performance information during competition entails self-evaluation in social comparison (how I did) even though parametric modulator is own score; thus it indexes self-related evaluation under social comparison.

Competition context requires maintaining and comparing to an opponent’s performance (social comparison), even if modulator is own score; neural effects in competition condition reflect processing within a framework involving others’ abilities/performance.

Feedback phase includes socially competitive manipulation (feedback includes opponent performance in competition condition) and engages mentalizing network; analysis targets feedback processing differences/activations relevant to social comparison.

Feedback during competition involves social comparison/competition (explicit example under affiliation/attachment construct). Event-related feedback analysis captures neural responses during this competitive interaction context.

Although it is social, the feedback is numeric/score-based rather than communicative cue reception/production (faces, gaze, speech). This analysis is not primarily about social communication processing.
Feedback entails evaluation of one's own performance, particularly in social comparison context, engaging self-referential processing.
In competition feedback, participants see and interpret opponent performance, requiring representation of others’ abilities and comparison; engages understanding of others in a competitive context.
Contrast Competition > No competition isolates social competition manipulation at feedback (includes opponent info), directly measuring social processing effects (mPFC, PCC/precuneus, STS).

Direct competition vs noncompetition contrast is a canonical social comparison/competition manipulation, fitting affiliation/attachment construct examples; measures differential processing of competitive social context.
No explicit social communication cues (faces/voices/gestures) are manipulated; contrast is about competition context in feedback rather than communicative signal processing.
Competition vs no-competition feedback changes self-evaluation context (performance with social comparison), thus measuring self-referential evaluative processing differences.
Competition feedback uniquely includes others’ performance information; contrast isolates processing of opponent-related information and social comparison.

No Competition > Competition is the inverse of the competition manipulation; still a social-processing relevant contrast because it compares social vs nonsocial contexts during feedback/working memory (depending on table).
Inverse contrast still measures effects of competitive social context (reduced activation in competition or greater in no-competition), within competition/social comparison construct.
Does not isolate communicative cue processing; it is about competition context.
Contrast alters self-evaluative context; inverse direction still indexes self-processing differences under social comparison vs solo feedback.
Contrast compares conditions with vs without opponent information; even inverse direction reflects processing related to understanding others in competition.

Table 1 reports ROI definition/characteristics (voxel counts, peak coordinates, subjects meeting voxel criterion) and does not test or contrast any social-cognitive process or behavior.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation or contrast (e.g., bonding, loved-one, cooperation/competition) is tested; this is ROI metadata only.
No social communication measure/contrast is evaluated in this table; it only documents ROI localization parameters.
No self-referential judgment/agency/self-knowledge component is analyzed; table contains only ROI setup information.
Although the broader study involves perceiving others’ facial emotion/age, this specific table does not report an analysis/contrast of perceiving others; it reports ROI definition metrics only.
Whole-brain searchlight decoding of facial emotional valence (negative vs positive) involves processing socially relevant facial affect, a core social perception process.
Contrast is emotional valence perception, not bonding/affiliation/attachment or relationship-relevant comparisons.
Decoding emotional expression valence from dynamic faces is receptive facial communication (affect recognition) and thus measures social communication processes.
No judgments about the self (traits, agency, self-knowledge) are involved; participants judge face properties of others.
Classifying negative vs positive facial expressions measures perception/understanding of others’ emotional states (emotion recognition).
Within the emotion-attention condition, decoding facial emotional valence (negative vs positive) directly indexes social-affective processing of faces.
The contrast concerns perceived valence of facial expression, not attachment/affiliative bonding constructs.
Task requires receptive interpretation of facial emotional expressions (a component of facial social communication).
No self-referential processing is assessed; the analysis is about perceiving others’ facial affect.
Negative vs positive emotion decoding in faces reflects understanding others’ emotional states.

Even when attention is directed to age, the searchlight attempts to decode facial emotional valence from dynamic faces, which is still a social-perception (social information) analysis, regardless of null findings.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation is present; it is emotion valence decoding under an age-attention task.
The stimulus feature being decoded is facial emotion (receptive facial communication), even though participants attend to age and decoding may be absent.
No self-focused judgments are performed; analysis targets properties of other faces.
Decoding others’ facial emotional valence (even under inattention) is perception/understanding of others’ emotional states.

Social joke-telling interaction task; contrast isolates self-action relevance when hearing listener response (self vs other), a core social-processing manipulation.
Although socially rewarding, the contrast tests self-relevance/agency (self vs other speaker) rather than relationship bonding, attachment, kinship, or cooperation/competition constructs.

Contrast concerns communicative context (participant vs other delivering jokes) and processing feedback directed to self within an interpersonal exchange (listener response), fitting non-facial receptive social communication.
Direct self vs other (agency/self-relevance) manipulation while monitoring outcome of one's own action; targets self-related processing (mPFC).
Does not require inferring others’ mental states/traits; it contrasts self vs other speaker (agency) rather than reasoning about the listener/other person.
Task is social (listener laughter feedback); contrast tests processing of social auditory feedback (group laughter vs none) during interaction context.
Contrast reflects sensory/affective response to laughter intensity, not formation/assessment of social bonds or attachment.
Listener laughter is non-facial communicative feedback; contrast measures reception of socially meaningful vocal/auditory response (laughter vs silence).
Collapsed across SELF and OTHER; contrast is about auditory response type (laughter vs none) rather than self-related judgments/agency.
Laughter is an other-generated social signal indicating others’ affective response; contrast indexes perception of others’ response (auditory social cue) even without explicit mentalizing.
Social interaction context; contrast tests processing of listener laughter (single) vs no laughter, i.e., social feedback.
No manipulation of social bonding/attachment; focuses on presence of laughter as feedback.
Measures reception of non-facial social communication signal (laughter vs silence).
Collapsed across SELF and OTHER; not self-referential evaluation or agency contrast.
Indexes perception of another person’s affective response (laughter) as an auditory social cue.
Compares degrees of social feedback (group vs single laughter) within a social interaction paradigm.
Difference between group and single laughter reflects intensity/salience of feedback, not attachment or bonding.
Laughter magnitude is a communicative cue; contrast measures differential processing of nonverbal auditory social communication.
Collapsed across SELF and OTHER; not primarily self-referential/agency processing.
Assesses perception of others’ response strength (group vs single laughter) as a social signal.
Interaction contrast isolates social action-outcome contingency: others’ laughter contingent on one’s own action vs another’s action; central social processing construct.
Although rewarding, it measures contingency/value of feedback rather than bonding/attachment or relationship closeness.
Depends on communicative feedback (laughter vs none) and its contingency on speaker, capturing how social feedback is integrated in interaction.
Requires differentiating outcomes contingent on self vs other actions (agency/self-relevance) to compute the interaction term.
Requires processing others’ responses (laughter/no laughter) and integrating them with who acted; reflects perception of others’ affective feedback.
Same social contingency interaction but for single laughter vs no laughter; still assesses social action-outcome contingency (even though null results).
Not an attachment/bonding manipulation; tests contingency of feedback.
Integrates communicative feedback (single laughter) contingent on speaker; a social communication-based contrast.
Interaction depends on self vs other agency in generating outcome contingencies.
Includes processing of the listener’s response as other-generated affective feedback.
PPI tests network integration during a social interaction task; connectivity between self-related mPFC and auditory cortex predicting ventral striatum engagement in processing social feedback.
Connectivity analysis targets self-relevance gating of sensory feedback/value, not attachment bonds or affiliation learning per se.
Uses auditory cortex (processing laughter) and mPFC to examine integration of communicative feedback with self-related signals—core to non-facial receptive social communication.
One seed is mPFC defined by self-action effect; PPI explicitly tests how self-related activity modulates connectivity to process outcomes.
Other seed is auditory cortex responsive to listener laughter; PPI concerns processing of others’ affective response signals integrated with self-related signals.
Same PPI question as analysis_6 but with left auditory cortex; examines social interaction network integrating self and others’ response signals.
Not measuring attachment/affiliation bonding constructs; focuses on self-modulated sensory-reward connectivity.
Auditory communicative feedback (laughter) integrated with self-related mPFC activity; receptive non-facial social communication.
mPFC seed reflects self-related processing; PPI tests self-related modulation of connectivity.
Auditory cortex seed reflects perception of others’ laughter; PPI tests integration with self-related signals.

Task involves evaluating news for personal selection vs control; selecting content engages social processing constructs (self- and other-relevance) per study design, and contrast measures neural activity during that social-cognitive/self-referential decision process relative to content recall.

Select>content is about deciding to read an article oneself; it does not explicitly involve forming/assessing social bonds, attachment, or affiliation targets (no loved-one/relationship manipulation).
No communicative exchange is required in select>content; participants are not sending/receiving social signals, producing or interpreting communicative cues.
Selecting to read for oneself requires assessing self-relevance/preference; contrast isolates this self-referential valuation/judgment relative to content recall.

Although selecting is for self, study rationale indicates participants may consider social implications/others; whole-brain/ROI include mentalizing network engagement during selection vs content recall, thus measuring other-related processing.
Share>content directly contrasts social sharing decisions with a control task, measuring social processing engaged during considering sharing news with others.

Sharing with others (broadcast/narrowcast) is a socially connecting behavior aligned with affiliative motivation (bonding/connecting), and contrast measures neural activity during this affiliative sharing decision relative to content recall.
Sharing information is a prototypical social-communication act (transmission of socially relevant information); share>content measures neural activity during that communicative intention/decision.
Sharing decisions involve self-related evaluation (self-presentation, self-relevance) as described; contrast captures self-referential processing during sharing vs control.
Sharing inherently requires considering recipients/others’ perspectives (mentalizing); contrast isolates other-related processing during sharing vs content recall.
Share>select directly compares two decision contexts differing in social orientation, capturing increased social-processing demands during sharing relative to self-selection.
Sharing (vs selecting) more strongly engages affiliative/connection motives (communicating to others, bonding) per study hypothesis; contrast measures this relative increase.
Contrast isolates communicative intent/processes (sharing information outward) relative to private selection, thus measuring social communication differences.

Both conditions involve self-evaluation, but share>select can still reflect differential self-presentation/self-relevance demands during sharing; study reports heightened self-related ROI activity for sharing vs selecting.
Sharing requires greater consideration of others’ mental states than selecting for oneself; share>select targets this increased other-oriented processing.
Parametric modulation by preference during select trials measures social-processing components (self- and potentially other-related) engaged while deciding personal selection, as framed in the study.
Preference to select for oneself is not an affiliation/attachment manipulation and does not index relationship bonding or attachment-specific processes.
Selecting articles for personal reading is not a communication act; modulation reflects private preference rather than information exchange.
Preference rating modulation during select trials directly indexes self-referential valuation/liking and self-relevance while choosing content for oneself.
Study posits social considerations during selection and reports social-cognition ROI modulation with selection preferences; thus modulation can reflect other-related processing linked to preference.
Parametric modulation by preference during share trials measures social processing engaged as participants evaluate likelihood of sharing with others.
Higher preference to share plausibly reflects stronger affiliative/connection motives; modulation tests how neural activity scales with this affiliative inclination during sharing.
Preference-modulated activity during sharing directly indexes neural processes scaling with communicative intent to transmit information to others.
Sharing preference involves self-related considerations (self-presentation, self-relevance); modulation captures how self-processing scales with willingness to share.
Willingness to share depends on considering others/recipients; modulation captures scaling of mentalizing/other-understanding with sharing preference.

Contrast from Trust Game (economic social exchange) during which participants decide whether to reciprocate another player's prior trust. This is a social-interaction decision context and thus measures social processing broadly.

The Trust Game operationalizes cooperative/reciprocal exchange (prosocial vs selfish choices) which falls under affiliation-related social interaction (cooperation/competition) even though partners are anonymous and not attachment figures.
No communicative signals are perceived or produced (no faces, gaze, language exchange); task is an economic decision about giving money, not social communication processing.

Decision reflects one's own reciprocal/selfish choice and engages self-related evaluation (e.g., weighing own payoff vs norm compliance); contrast isolates the choice not to reciprocate, implicating self-guided decision/agency.

Even in 'Gave $0' trials, the decision is made in response to another player's prior investment/trust, requiring representation of the other agent's action and implied expectations (action/mental-state understanding).
Trust Game contrast for reciprocating after receiving money from another player; directly measures social reciprocity in an interpersonal exchange.
Reciprocation following partner's reciprocity is cooperative/prosocial exchange behavior, aligning with affiliation/cooperation constructs.
Task does not involve decoding or producing social communicative cues; it is a monetary decision only.
Contrast reflects participant's own choice to give back (agency/decision), involving self-related valuation and norm-based action selection.
Choice is contingent on partner's prior action of reciprocating (receiving money), requiring processing of the other agent's behavior and intentions in the exchange.
Trust Game contrast for reciprocating even after the other player previously did not reciprocate; still a social exchange decision capturing social processing broadly.
Prosocial/cooperative behavior in an exchange context (reciprocation despite unfairness) maps onto affiliation/cooperation constructs rather than attachment per se.
No explicit communicative content (faces/voices/language/gaze); monetary decision only.
Isolates participant's own altruistic/reciprocal choice (agency) despite negative outcome, involving self-guided moral/value-based decision making.

Decision explicitly depends on knowledge that the other player did not reciprocate, requiring representation of other's prior action and likely intentions/fairness (action perception/mental-state inference).
Contrast compares altruistic reciprocation vs non-reciprocation after not receiving from partner; directly tests social decision-making in an interpersonal reciprocity context.
Difference between giving vs not giving in response to partner's non-reciprocation operationalizes prosocial cooperation vs selfishness, fitting affiliation/cooperation constructs.
Contrast does not involve reception/production of communicative signals; it is an economic choice contrast.
Directly contrasts participant's own action selection (give vs not give), emphasizing agency and self-related valuation/moral choice.

Both conditions are defined by the partner's prior non-reciprocation; the contrast isolates response to another's unfair action, which requires representation of the other agent's behavior and implied mental states.

Participants observed another person's socially embarrassing mishaps (social integrity threats) and rated an interpersonal social emotion (vicarious embarrassment/fremdscham) vs neutral social scenes, directly engaging social cognition/empathy networks.

Task involves observing strangers in public mishaps; no manipulation or measurement of bonding/attachment, close relationships, or affiliative interactions (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition for bonding).

Stimuli are static sketches with vignettes; the contrast targets emotional appraisal of others’ predicaments, not reception/production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, gestures) as a primary construct.

Although participants introspectively rate their own felt emotion, the experimental manipulation/contrast is centered on responses to others’ social integrity threats rather than self-referential judgments about traits/agency or explicit self-knowledge tasks.

Fremdscham requires understanding the target's embarrassment/social integrity threat and likely engages reasoning about the other’s state; contrast is SIT>NEUT while attending to vicarious embarrassment for the target.
Participants observed social integrity threats involving another person and rated schadenfreude (amusement at another’s mishap) vs neutral scenes, a social-emotional processing task.
No assessment/manipulation of attachment or affiliative bonding; targets are strangers and the emotion is not an affiliative/attachment construct.
Contrast does not isolate communicative signal processing or interaction; it examines affective evaluation of others’ mishaps in drawings with text.
Not an explicit self-knowledge/agency task; ratings are about amusement but the contrast is driven by others’ predicaments rather than self-referential evaluation.
Schadenfreude in response to another’s misfortune entails representing the other’s predicament and its social meaning; the SIT>NEUT contrast is anchored in processing others’ social situations.

Direct group comparison (Fremdscham > Schadenfreude) tests differential social-emotional processing contexts while observing others’ social integrity threats, i.e., social processing is the measured construct.
Comparison reflects empathic embarrassment vs amusement; it does not involve relationship bonding/attachment or affiliative interaction manipulations.
Does not target processing/production of communicative cues; differences relate to empathic vs reward-focused appraisal of others’ mishaps.

Although instructional set differs (focus on own experience), the contrast is not an explicit self-referential/agency measure; it's mainly about how others’ integrity threats are processed under different motivational stances.
The difference isolates greater empathic/vicarious embarrassment processing, which depends on understanding/representing the other’s social-emotional state more than the amusement-focused condition.

Participants viewed romantic couple images (romantic > neutral), a clearly social/relationship-relevant stimulus category; the contrast measures neural processing of social-affiliative content relative to neutral scenes.

Romantic stimuli depict pair-bonding/affiliative interactions (e.g., hugging/hand-holding). The romantic > neutral contrast targets attachment/affiliation-related processing rather than general visual processing alone.

Although images include couples, the task/contrast is not designed to isolate communication cues (e.g., faces/gaze, prosody, gesture interpretation) or communicative exchange; it focuses on romantic/affiliative reward processing.
No explicit self-referential judgment, self-trait evaluation, or agency/self-knowledge manipulation; participants passively viewed images.

The contrast does not require inferring others’ mental states/emotions or action understanding; it is primarily romantic-affiliative content vs neutral without explicit theory-of-mind/mentalizing demands.

Contrast involves romantic vs sexual stimuli (romantic > sexual) within the non-monogamous group; both are socially relevant, and the contrast measures differential processing of romantic relationship content, a social domain.
Romantic (pair-bond/affiliation) content is contrasted against sexual content; this comparison taps attachment/affiliative valuation and processing differences specific to romantic bonding.
The analysis does not specifically target receptive/expressive communication (faces, gaze, gesture, speech); it is a content comparison of romantic bonding vs sexual scenes.
No self-referential appraisal or self-knowledge task component is manipulated in the romantic > sexual contrast.
No explicit requirement to infer others’ mental states or emotions; increased cortical activations are interpreted as cognitive processing but not operationalized as mentalizing.

IAT stimuli and categorizations are explicitly social/relationship-related (monogamy vs adultery pictures; good vs bad), and the contrast incongruent>congruent indexes processing of socially meaningful concepts/attitudes toward relationship behavior, thus measuring social processing broadly.

Task targets relationship maintenance attitudes (monogamy vs adultery), directly tied to pair-bond/attachment-related constructs; incongruent>congruent reflects processing/conflict around those affiliation-related associations.

Although images depict couples, the task does not require decoding communicative signals (faces/gaze/expressions) or exchanging information; it is categorization of concepts/valence rather than social communication.
No explicit self-referential judgment or self-trait/state evaluation is required; contrast reflects conflict/inhibition during categorization rather than self-knowledge/agency processing.

Participants are not asked to infer others' mental states/traits or interpret actions; stimuli are used as category exemplars (monogamy/adultery) without requiring mentalizing or action understanding.
This reverse contrast (congruent>incongruent) yielded no significant activation; thus there is no measured social-processing effect to annotate for this analysis.
No significant activation for congruent>incongruent, so no identifiable affiliation/attachment-related neural effect is measured in this analysis.
No significant activation and the contrast does not specifically probe social communication processes.
No significant activation and the contrast is not self-referential in nature.
No significant activation and the contrast does not involve mental state/action inference about others.

Movie-watching task involves observing a moral dilemma between sisters with manipulation of perceived kinship (genetic vs adopted). The contrast genetic>non-genetic reflects differential neural synchrony during socially relevant moral/kinship processing, i.e., social cognition.

Manipulation is explicitly about kinship/relationship status (genetic vs adoptive sisters), a core affiliation/attachment-related social bond construct; contrast tests effect of perceived kinship on processing.

Although stimulus is a social interaction in a movie, the analysis/contrast is not specifically about communicative signals (faces/gaze/voice/gesture) or communication vs control; it targets kinship framing effects on moral dilemma processing.
Participants are not making explicit self-referential judgments about their own traits/states, nor agency/self-knowledge contrasts; they passively view a movie with different kinship framing.

Task requires understanding/evaluating others (the sisters) in a moral dilemma; kinship framing likely modulates mentalizing/understanding others’ intentions and emotions. The contrast measures differential processing of others under genetic vs adoptive framing.

Reverse contrast (non-genetic>genetic) still derives from the same social/moral movie-watching task; it measures condition-related differences in processing a social dilemma even if effects localize to visual cortex.
Contrast isolates effects of perceived non-kin (adoptive) vs kin framing while viewing sisters; still an affiliation/kinship manipulation even if resulting ISC differences are in occipital regions.
Not a communication-specific manipulation/contrast; higher ISC in occipital cortex likely reflects visual processing differences rather than receptive/expressive social communication measures.
No self-referential judgment/agency manipulation; contrast concerns perceived relationship between others in the movie.
Even in the non-genetic framing, viewers are perceiving and evaluating others in a moral interaction; the contrast measures how understanding of others changes with relationship framing.

Moral dilemma decision task requires choosing whom to save (sister, best friend, strangers), a socially relevant moral/relationship-based decision; decision vs non-decision contrast measures social cognition engaged during such choices.

Choices explicitly involve close relationships (own sister, best friend) versus strangers, engaging affiliation/attachment and kin preference; the task measures relationship-based prioritization even though the reported GLM contrast is decision vs non-decision.

Task is a text/picture-based decision paradigm about rescuing individuals, not centered on processing communicative cues (faces, prosody, gaze) or producing communication; contrast is decision-making vs watching background story.
While participants make choices, the analysis is not about self-knowledge/agency or self-referential evaluation; it contrasts decision periods with non-decision story periods in a moral scenario.

Decisions require representing others’ identities and value (sister/friend/strangers) and likely their states; thus engages perception/understanding of others. The decision vs non-decision contrast captures this other-focused social evaluation component.

Participants judged whether a human(-like) walker stimulus (PLD or HL) was facing toward vs away, requiring processing of socially relevant biological motion cues; contrast FT>FA tests modulation by social involvement cues.
Task does not assess bonding, affiliation, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-related evaluation; it is a perceptual direction judgment.
No communicative exchange or decoding/producing communicative signals (facial/non-facial) is required beyond basic action direction perception.
No self-referential judgments, agency attribution to self, or self-knowledge measures; participants judge external stimulus direction.
Contrast involves perception of others’ actions/animacy (biological motion walker) and interpretation of its orientation relative to observer.
FA>FT contrasts conditions differing in perceived social involvement while observing biological motion/human-like agents, within a social-perceptual task.
Does not involve attachment/affiliation relationships or bonding-related judgments.
No explicit communication (facial/non-facial) reception/production; it is action direction discrimination.
No self-focused evaluation or agency; only other-stimulus direction judgment.
Indexes action perception/animacy processing of another agent’s movement direction.
HL>PLD contrasts two types of biological-agent stimuli differing in richness/human-likeness, during a task about others’ movement direction; measures social perception processing differences.
Stimuli are not loved ones/ingroup-outgroup etc.; no affiliation or bonding manipulation.
Although human-like bodies are viewed, the task is not communicative signal decoding/production; it's direction judgment.
No self-referential or agency/self-knowledge component.
Directly contrasts perception of others’ actions/animacy from HL videos vs PLD.
PLD>HL tests differences in processing observed biological motion representations of others during a social-perceptual direction task.
No affiliative/attachment manipulation or relationship evaluation present.
Task is not social communication; it does not require interpreting communicative gestures or facial signals.
Not about self-related processing.
Contrasts two depictions of others’ actions (PLD vs human-like), indexing action/animacy perception.
Stimulus type × direction interaction tests how social-involvement cues modulate processing of observed agents (PLD/HL) in a social perception task.
No attachment/affiliation constructs measured; interaction is about perceptual/social involvement cues not relationship bonding.
No communicative exchange/signaling manipulation; interaction pertains to action direction and stimulus format.
No self-referential judgment or agency attribution to self.
Interaction concerns perception/interpretation of others' actions (direction/orientation) across stimulus types.
Post-hoc tests decompose the interaction between stimulus type and direction during observation of biological motion, still measuring social perception.
No affiliative/attachment dimension assessed in post-hoc contrasts.
Post-hoc contrasts do not isolate communication processes; they compare action-direction conditions and stimulus representations.
No self-related processing tested in these post-hoc contrasts.
Post-hoc contrasts examine how perception of others’ actions varies by stimulus type and direction.
FT_PLD>HL compares PLD vs HL specifically in facing-toward condition during action-direction judgments, a social perception manipulation.
Not an affiliation/attachment contrast; no relationship or bonding component.
Not assessing communicative signaling; it is biological motion format comparison.
No self-perception/self-knowledge component.
Directly compares perception of others’ actions across stimulus representations in FT condition.
FT_HL>PLD contrasts human-like vs point-light representations when the agent faces toward the observer, within a social action-perception task.
No attachment/affiliation measurement.
Not communication per se; no message exchange or communicative gesture decoding beyond action orientation.
Not self-focused.
Assesses action/animacy perception of others across stimulus types in FT condition.
FA_PLD>HL compares PLD vs HL when the agent faces away, probing social-involvement/action-perception processing differences.
No affiliative/attachment construct manipulated.
No communication task; just direction judgment with different stimulus formats.
Not self perception/agency.
Evaluates perception of others’ actions from PLD vs HL in FA condition.
FA_HL>PLD contrasts human-like vs point-light walkers in facing-away condition during social action perception task.
No bonding/relationship-related processing.
Does not involve communicative exchange or decoding communicative intent; it is action orientation perception.
No self-referential processing.
Contrasts representations of others’ actions (HL vs PLD) in FA condition.
PLD_FT>FA compares movement direction within PLD biological motion, testing social-involvement cue effects in action perception.
No affiliation/attachment measure; direction manipulation is not bonding.
Direction judgment is not a communication task.
Not about self-related cognition.
Assesses perception of others’ actions (PLD) varying in direction relative to observer.
PLD_FA>FT tests direction effects within point-light biological motion observation, a social action-perception task.
No affiliative/attachment construct involved.
Not assessing communication signals; only action direction.
No self-perception component.
Direction-dependent processing of others’ actions from PLD.
HL_FT>FA compares direction (toward vs away) for human-like walkers, indexing social involvement cues during action perception.
No relationship/bonding evaluation.
Not a communication task; no explicit communicative content is exchanged.
No self-related judgment involved.
Perception of others’ actions varying by approach/avoidance direction in HL stimuli.
HL_FA>FT contrasts facing-away vs facing-toward in human-like stimuli during action-direction judgments, measuring social perception modulation.
No affiliative/attachment construct measured.
No social communication component beyond perceiving motion direction.
Not self-perception/self-knowledge.
Evaluates perception of others' actions with differing orientation relative to observer in HL videos.

Retrieval performed in an interactive referential communication game with a partner; contrast tests effects of collaborative vs arbitrary learning context, engaging social-cognition network per paper.
Task involves cooperation/interaction but contrast is not designed to measure bonding/attachment or affiliation-specific processes (no loved-one, closeness, attachment manipulation).
In-scanner task is a communicative exchange (director names label for matcher to select picture). Contrast reflects retrieval in this communicative setting with collaborative-encoding influence.
Primary manipulation concerns memory retrieval for labels learned in different contexts; no explicit self-judgment/agency/self-knowledge contrast.

Although authors interpret collaborative effects as mentalizing, this specific contrast is collaborative vs arbitrary (confounded with self-generation/semantics) and does not isolate reasoning about others’ mental states.

Contrast compares individually self-generated vs arbitrary labels during retrieval; although performed in a communicative game, manipulation targets semantic/self-generation memory differences rather than social processing.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation or measure.
Both conditions occur within same communicative task; contrast does not measure variation in communication processes.
Not an explicit self-referential/agency contrast; focuses on retrieval of self-generated vs arbitrary labels.
No manipulation requiring reasoning about others’ states.

Contrast directly tests collaboratively vs individually learned labels, isolating effect of prior social interaction/collaboration on retrieval; interpreted as engaging mentalizing/autobiographical network (mPFC, rTPJ, precuneus).
Collaboration is present but not operationalized as affiliation/attachment or bonding; no attachment-relevant stimuli or measures.

Learning context differs by whether labels were established through communicative interaction with partner; contrast measures effect of collaborative communication on later retrieval during communicative task.
Not focused on self-evaluation or agency; differences attributed mainly to social-cognitive processing about partner/common ground.
Collaborative vs individual encoding requires tracking partner’s understanding/common ground; authors link activation to theory of mind/mentalizing (understanding others’ mental states).
Contrast arbitrary vs individual mainly indexes associative/hippocampal demands of arbitrary word-picture learning, not social processing.
No affiliation/attachment construct tested.
Communication context held constant; contrast targets memory system differences.
Not a self-perception/self-knowledge manipulation.
No explicit others-mental-state reasoning manipulation.
Reverse of Collaborative > Individual; still tests effect of collaboration/social context on retrieval (individual learned labels relative to collaboratively learned).
Does not assess bonding/attachment.
Differs by whether labels were established via communicative collaboration; thus relates to social-communication component of learning context.
Not self-referential/agency.
By contrasting individual vs collaborative, it still indexes processes tied to representing a partner/common ground (others’ mental states) albeit in opposite direction.
Arbitrary vs collaborative compares retrieval of labels learned without vs with collaborative social interaction; involves social context difference (collaboration) within an interactive task.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation.
Contrast differs in whether labels were learned through social communication with partner (collaborative) versus alone (arbitrary).
Focus is memory retrieval/associative demands, not self-perception.

Although collaborative learning may involve mentalizing, this contrast is heavily confounded with self-generation/semantic vs arbitrary associations and does not specifically isolate understanding others’ mental states.

Participants observed pictures of human social interactions (cooperative or affective) versus baseline; this is a social-cognitive task measuring social processing broadly.

Stimuli depict positive cooperative and affective interactions; observing/processing cooperativity and affectivity taps affiliative bonding/cooperation dimension at the core of affiliation/attachment constructs, even though task is implicit.

Although scenes may contain communicative cues (e.g., handshakes/gaze), the contrast is generic observation of social interactions vs baseline and is not designed to isolate communication processes (receptive/expressive signaling) specifically.
No self-referential judgments, self-knowledge, or agency manipulation; participants passively observe and detect landscapes.
Observing others interacting necessarily involves action/animacy perception and implicit understanding of others’ intentions; the contrast captures perception/understanding of others broadly.
Contrast indexes neural sensitivity to cooperativity during observation of social interactions, a core social-processing manipulation.
Cooperativity explicitly targets cooperation/positive social bonding cues, aligning with affiliation/attachment processes.
The contrast targets cooperativity rather than communicative exchange per se; communicative signaling is not the measured construct.
No self-focused appraisal or agency manipulation.
Cooperativity requires interpreting others’ shared goals/actions (action perception and intention understanding).
Contrast indexes neural sensitivity to affective content of observed social interactions, a social-processing manipulation.
Affective interactions (e.g., affectionate contact, positive emotion) relate to affiliative/attachment-related processing of social bonding cues.
Although affective scenes may contain expressive cues, the contrast is not specifically about communication (e.g., decoding facial/gaze signals) but about affectivity dimension more broadly.
No manipulation requiring self-referential processing or agency.
Affectivity entails inferring others’ emotional/mental states (understanding mental states).

Analysis 29265483_analysis_3 refers to the DCM/effective connectivity model results table rather than a task contrast measuring social processing via activation differences; connectivity parameters are not a standard social-processing contrast in this annotation framework.
DCM connectivity/modulation parameters are not a direct measure/contrast of affiliative/attachment processing in the sense required by the annotations; they model coupling among ROIs.
No communication-specific contrast; DCM parameters do not isolate communicative exchange processes.
No self-perception component; effective connectivity analysis does not constitute self-related task/contrast.
While DCM is based on observing others, this analysis entry is connectivity parameter estimation rather than a contrast measuring perception/understanding of others as defined by the framework.

Contrast tests effects of interacting with a human partner via haptic coupling (partnered: Leading/Following/Mutual) versus performing similar movements alone (Solo/Alone). This directly measures social interaction/joint action and recruits mentalizing/social perception regions (e.g., TPJ, mPFC, pSTS) per study report.

Although partnered interaction is cooperative, the contrast is not designed to measure affiliative bonding/attachment or social relationship valuation (no loved one/attachment manipulation; primarily haptic joint action vs alone).
Partnering vs non-partnering isolates interpersonal information exchange through haptic cues (signaling/perceiving movement intentions), a form of non-facial social communication within joint action.
Contrast focuses on presence/absence of partner rather than self-referential judgment or explicit agency/self-knowledge; any self-monitoring is ancillary and not what the contrast measures.

Partnering requires perceiving/tracking another agent’s actions and intentions through touch; reported activations include pSTS/TPJ/mPFC consistent with action perception and mental-state understanding.
Leading-specific activity is derived after controlling for non-partnered movement and shared partnering effects, targeting the leader role within joint action (a social-interactive context).
Leader-role contrast does not manipulate affiliation, attachment, or bonding; it mainly indexes motor planning/self-initiation in an interaction.
Leading entails producing haptic cues/signals to guide the partner’s movement (productive non-facial communication) within joint action, even though the neural signature is largely motoric.

Leader role emphasizes internally driven/self-initiated action and self-monitoring (agency-like processes) compared with other partnered roles after controls; this aligns with perception/understanding of self (agency).

This contrast is constructed to capture what is specific to leading after removing common partnering; it primarily reflects self-initiated motor planning rather than perceiving/mentalizing about the other.
Following-specific activity (after removing non-partnered movement and shared partnering) targets the follower role in joint action, a social-interactive process reliant on partner-generated cues.
No assessment of bonding/attachment; contrast reflects sensory tracking and outcome monitoring during following.
Following requires receptive processing of non-facial communicative signals (haptic force/motion cues) from the partner to coordinate behavior.
Not an explicit self-awareness/self-knowledge manipulation; although outcome monitoring may involve self, the measured effect is responsiveness to partner cues.

Follower role centers on perceiving and predicting the other’s actions/intentions (action perception; mental-state inference) via haptic/motion tracking; reported pSTS/MT+/TPJ/mPFC involvement supports this.

Mutual-specific activity (after controlling for non-partnered movement and shared partnering) captures symmetric joint interaction with enhanced mentalizing/reward responses, thus measuring social processing within interaction.

Mutual condition is the most cooperative/reciprocal interaction and shows greater activation in social reward regions (e.g., nucleus accumbens, amygdala) relative to other partnered roles, consistent with affiliative/cooperative bonding-related processes.
Mutual coordination requires bidirectional exchange and integration of partner cues (non-facial communication) to maintain synchrony without explicit leader/follower roles.
Although agency may be ambiguous, the contrast is not designed to probe self-referential judgments; primary reported specificity is mentalizing/reward about the interaction.
Mutual interaction preferentially engages mentalizing network (mPFC/TPJ/PCC), reflecting reasoning about partner intentions and shared agency, i.e., understanding others’ mental states.

Improvisation contrast (Leading+Solo > Mutual+Alone) targets motor improvisation/generation vs pre-learned sequences, collapsing across partnered and non-partnered contexts; it is not a social-processing measure per se.
No affiliative/attachment manipulation; contrast is about improvisation.
Does not isolate interpersonal communication; includes solo improvisation and compares to fixed patterns.
While improvisation involves self-generation, this is not framed as self-perception/agency judgment; it is primarily motor planning/working memory.
No requirement to perceive/understand others is isolated by this contrast; includes solo condition.

Self-initiation contrast ([Leading+Solo+Mutual+Alone] > Following) isolates internally driven vs externally driven movement initiation, not a social-processing construct; it can be executed without social reasoning (e.g., Alone contributes).
No affiliation/attachment content.
Not a communication contrast; it contrasts externally triggered following vs self-initiated conditions including non-partnered Alone.
Contrast directly targets self-initiated (internally generated) action vs externally triggered action, aligning with agency/self-initiation aspects of perception/understanding of self.
Although Following involves responding to another, the contrast is framed as internal vs external triggering rather than representing others’ mental states.

Joint improvisation analyses (e.g., Leading vs Solo; interaction-type contrasts) in this study primarily probe whether partnering adds anything beyond solo improvisation/skin contact; the reported effects are either basic partnering somatosensory additions or null for interaction. They do not clearly measure social processing beyond what is captured by the dedicated partnering contrast.
No bonding/attachment manipulation; contrasts are about improvisation-with-partner vs solo and largely yield partnering sensory regions or null.
Although conceptually about signaling intentions, the tested contrasts did not isolate a communicative process beyond general partnering effects (and interaction effects were null).
Not an explicit self-perception/agency contrast; focuses on interaction between improvisation and partnership, largely null.
Does not isolate action/mental-state perception of others; any partner-related effects are better captured in the Partnering contrast and role-specific Following/Mutual analyses.

Task involves viewing erotic pictures (sexual stimuli) and contrasting female>male within heterosexual women. This is sexual arousal/visual processing, not designed to measure social processing constructs (communication, affiliation, self/other understanding).
No manipulation of social bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-related cues; contrast is based on stimulus sex in erotic images.
No social communication task (e.g., facial affect recognition, gaze, communicative signals) and contrast does not isolate communicative processing; it is erotic picture viewing by sex.
Contrast does not require self-referential judgment or self-knowledge; it measures evoked responses to erotic pictures by depicted sex.
Although stimuli depict people, the task/contrast is not designed to assess reasoning about others' actions/mental states; it's sexual stimulus processing by sex.
Male>female erotic pictures within heterosexual women reflects differential sexual/visual processing to stimulus sex, not a social processing construct.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation; erotic picture sex contrast only.
No communicative signal processing task or contrast; erotic images only.
No self-referential processing required; passive viewing/rating of erotic pictures by sex.
Not an explicit action/mental state understanding contrast; erotic stimulus sex comparison.
Female>male erotic pictures within bisexual women measures stimulus-sex differences in erotic/visual responses, not social processing.
No attachment/affiliation constructs or relationship manipulation; only erotic picture sex contrast.
Not a social communication paradigm; erotic picture viewing.

Despite person stimuli, no requirement to infer others’ states/actions; erotic sex contrast is not a social-cognition measure.
Male>female erotic pictures within bisexual women indexes sexual arousal/attention differences, not social processing constructs.
No bonding/attachment content or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger); only erotic picture sex contrast.
No explicit communicative cue processing; contrast is male vs female erotic pictures.
No self-referential evaluation required beyond general liking; not designed to measure self-perception/knowledge.
Not designed to probe understanding of others’ mental states/action perception; primarily erotic stimulus processing.

Does not measure self-perception/agency/self-knowledge; just stimulus-sex differences.

No explicit self-referential judgments; neural contrast is based on depicted sex of erotic video stimuli.
Not focused on understanding others’ actions/mental states; primarily erotic stimulus processing by sex.

Male>female erotic videos within bisexual women is a sexual stimulus contrast; despite discussion of possible mentalizing activations, the task itself does not measure social processing.

Although authors speculate about mentalizing/mirroring, the paradigm is not explicitly an others' mental state/action understanding task and contrast is not designed to measure it.

The contrast examines neural responses to affective vocalisations (human/chimp/macaque) and tests graded sensitivity to socially relevant emotional signals; this is a social-perceptual task engaging social processing (emotion/communicative cue perception).

Although stimuli include positive/negative vocalisations, the task/contrast does not assess bonding, attachment, affiliation, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-related judgments; it is auditory affect perception across species.

Participants process nonverbal affective vocalisations (a form of social communication signal) and the contrast isolates regions responding more to conspecific vs other-species vocal affect; this fits receptive non-facial social communication.
No self-referential judgments, self-knowledge, or agency/self-monitoring are manipulated; participants perform an attention task (car horn detection) while listening.

Affective vocalisations convey others’ emotional states; the analysis tests perception/understanding of others via decoding emotional social cues (across species), aligning with emotion/mental-state related perception of others.

Task contrast involves social-role judgments about the self vs a person (celebrity), engaging social-cognitive/self-referential processing; thus measures social processing broadly.
Contrast is self vs celebrity trait/role judgment; does not specifically probe bonding/attachment or close-relationship/affiliation processes (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation).
No communicative exchange or perception/production of social signals (faces, gaze, prosody); it is a semantic self-referential judgment task.
Participants judge whether social roles describe themselves; Self vs Celebrity isolates self-knowledge/self-referential evaluation.

Although celebrity is an other, the contrast is primarily designed to identify self-referential processing rather than understanding others' mental states/traits per se (no explicit other-evaluation condition in numerator).
Friend vs Celebrity requires judging social attributes of a close other vs another person, engaging person knowledge and social cognition; qualifies as social processing.
Uses a friend (close other) but the measured contrast is trait/role judgment friend vs celebrity, not attachment/affiliation processes (bonding, social reward, kinship, cooperation) explicitly.
No communicative interaction or decoding/production of social signals; semantic judgments only.
No self-judgment in this contrast; it focuses on others.
Participants evaluate whether social roles describe a friend; contrast isolates other-referential person-knowledge/trait attribution relative to another other (celebrity).
Moderation (Creativity×Interdependence) of Self vs Celebrity activity still pertains to a social self-referential task contrast; therefore measures social processing.
Interaction/regression on self-referential processing does not operationalize affiliation/attachment behaviors or bonding-specific contrasts.
No social communication component; regression is on self-judgment neural response.
Dependent contrast is self- vs celebrity-judgment; regression identifies self-knowledge/self-referential processing modulated by interdependence and creativity.
Analysis targets self-referential activity (self vs celebrity) rather than explicit understanding of others.
Moderation analysis uses Friend vs Celebrity person-judgment contrast; this is a social-cognitive (other-referential) task measure.
Although friend is close, the contrast operationalizes trait judgment about others, not affiliation/attachment behaviors or social bonding per se.
No communicative signal processing/production; regression concerns other-referential judgments.
No self condition in the dependent contrast.
Dependent contrast is friend vs celebrity, capturing representations/judgments about another person; regression assesses moderation of other-perception/understanding processes.
gPPI functional connectivity during Self vs Celebrity pertains to social/self-referential processing; connectivity patterns are a neural measure of that social task contrast.
Connectivity during self-referential judgments does not specifically index affiliation/attachment constructs.
No social communication manipulation; connectivity reflects self-referential processing network dynamics.
Seed/psychological contrast is self vs celebrity judgment, directly indexing self-referential processing and its connectivity.
Contrast focuses on self-referential processing rather than explicit reasoning about others.
gPPI functional connectivity during Friend vs Celebrity reflects network dynamics during other-referential social-role judgments; qualifies as social processing.
Uses a friend but task/contrast does not probe attachment/affiliation (bonding/reward/cooperation); it's semantic person-judgment connectivity.
No communicative perception/production component; connectivity is tied to person-judgment contrast.
Not a self-focused contrast.
Psychological contrast is friend vs celebrity; measures understanding/judgment of others and associated connectivity.
Regression/moderation of functional connectivity during Self vs Celebrity remains a social self-referential task measure (social processing).
Does not operationalize affiliation/attachment-specific processing.
No social communication manipulation; it is self-referential connectivity modulation.
Dependent connectivity contrast is self- vs celebrity-judgment; moderation examines self-related network coupling.
Analysis is not centered on understanding others; it isolates self-referential processing vs another person baseline.

Conjunction of all social interaction task conditions (competitive/cooperative/random) versus control; directly measures social interaction/mentalizing network engagement during a prisoner's dilemma game.

Task involves cooperation vs defection decisions in an iterated social exchange game, a canonical affiliation/cooperation paradigm even though partners are fictive; contrast (task>control conjunction) captures affiliative/cooperative social exchange processing broadly.

Although social interaction context is present, this analysis does not isolate communicative signal exchange (e.g., facial/non-facial communication reception/production); it models decision+feedback in a strategic game rather than communication processes per se.

No explicit self-reflection/agency/self-knowledge judgment contrast; decision/outcome phases are modeled but the conjunction targets social task engagement, not self-perception processes specifically.

Strategic interaction requires inference about partners' intentions (ToM); conjunction (task>control) indexes understanding of others/mental state reasoning components consistently engaged across partners.
Competitive>Cooperative interaction contrast in an iterated prisoner's dilemma directly tests differential social decision-making/mentalizing responses to a selfish vs cooperative partner.

Contrast compares interaction with a competitive (low affiliation) vs cooperative (high affiliation) partner in a cooperation/competition task, capturing processes relevant to affiliative/cooperative bonding vs exploitation avoidance.
No manipulation of communicative cues or expression/reception; contrast is about partner strategy (competition vs cooperation) during decisions/outcomes, not communication channels.
Does not require explicit self-evaluation or self-knowledge; contrast focuses on partner type effects rather than self-referential judgments.
Competitive>Cooperative isolates increased processing of others' intentions/goals when the partner is noncooperative, consistent with understanding mental states/ToM demands.
Competitive>Cooperative (table labeled) is the same core strategic social interaction contrast, measuring differential social processing by partner cooperativeness.
Directly contrasts low-affiliation (competitive) vs high-affiliation (cooperative) partner interaction in a cooperation/competition task.
Strategic choices and outcome feedback are modeled; no communication-specific reception/production contrast.
Not designed to elicit self-knowledge/agency judgments; partner-strategy manipulation predominates.
Requires evaluating and updating beliefs about the partner’s intentions; Competitive>Cooperative increases mental-state inference/other-understanding demands.
Early phase Competitive>Cooperative targets the initial interaction period when social inference and adaptation are strongest; still a social decision-making/ToM contrast.
Early interaction emphasizes learning about a partner’s cooperative vs competitive strategy in a cooperation/competition setting, relevant to affiliative approach/avoidance in social exchange.
No explicit communicative cue processing; early-phase modulation pertains to strategic interaction/learning rather than communication behaviors.
Early-phase contrast does not require self-referential appraisal; it indexes response to partner behavior category.
Early-phase contrast is especially tied to inferring the partner’s intentions and updating beliefs (Understanding Mental States) when evidence is first accumulated.
gPPI/functional connectivity modulated by dynamic ToM value in Competitive>Cooperative context assesses individual differences in social decision-making adaptation and associated neural coupling.

Dynamic ToM reflects differential adaptation to competitive vs cooperative partners (cooperation/competition), a key affiliation-related construct; connectivity linked to this adaptation is within affiliative/strategic social exchange processing.
Connectivity analysis is about strategic interaction/adaptation, not about transmitting/receiving communicative signals (facial/non-facial) per se.
Although behavior varies across partners, the regressor/covariate is not explicit self-perception or self-knowledge; it indexes adaptation to others’ strategies.
Dynamic ToM operationalizes understanding others’ intentions across partners; connectivity associated with this value reflects processes supporting mental-state representation of others.

This analysis is an automated meta-analysis (NeuroSynth reverse inference) explicitly targeting studies with prominent social content (term 'social') to identify brain regions associated with social information processing. It therefore measures broad social processing as defined.

The meta-analysis is not focused on affiliation/attachment, bonding, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger type contrasts; it broadly aggregates diverse 'social' studies without isolating attachment-related constructs.

Although some included studies may involve communicative cues (e.g., faces), this particular analysis is not designed to measure social communication specifically; it is a term-based meta-analysis for general 'social' content rather than communication reception/production contrasts.

The analysis does not specifically measure self-referential processing or judgments about the self; it is a broad social keyword-based meta-analysis and cannot be attributed specifically to perception/understanding of self.

While many 'social' studies may involve perceiving/understanding others, this analysis is not a task/contrast specifically measuring perception/understanding of others (e.g., mental state attribution) but rather a broad term-based reverse inference map.

Main effect of modality collapses across facial/vocal/bimodal emotional expressions during an emotion valence discrimination task; task involves perceiving/labeling others' emotional expressions, a core social-cognitive process.
No manipulation of social bonding, affiliation, attachment relationships, cooperation/competition, or loved-one/close-other content; stimuli are generic actor expressions.
Participants process communicative social signals (facial expression and vocal prosody) to judge emotional valence; this is receptive social communication (facial and non-facial).
Task does not require self-referential judgments, agency, or introspection about one's own mental state; judgments are about stimulus valence.
Emotion perception from faces/voices requires assessing another individual's emotional state (anger/happy/neutral).
Main effect of emotion (anger/happy/neutral) during valence discrimination of dynamic facial/vocal/bimodal expressions indexes social-emotional perception of others.
Emotion-category effects are not about forming/maintaining social bonds or attachment-related evaluations.
Contrast reflects processing of communicated emotional signals (facial/vocal) across emotion categories in a receptive emotion-recognition task.
No self-focused appraisal or self-knowledge component; participants classify perceived stimulus emotion/valence.
Requires interpreting the actor’s emotional state conveyed by face/voice; the effect is driven by others' emotion categories.
Emotion×Modality interaction tests how perceiving others’ emotions differs across facial vs vocal channels; directly measures social-emotional processing across modalities.
Interaction concerns sensory modality and emotion category, not affiliative/attachment relationships or bonding-related behavior.
Examines differential neural responses to facial vs vocal emotional communication signals (receptive facial and non-facial communication).
No self-referential mentalizing or agency judgments; processing pertains to external social cues.
Interaction reflects decoding of another person’s emotional state from different expressive channels; thus pertains to understanding others.

Contrast compares agentic vs communal traits during self-evaluation, a social-cognitive/self-referential judgment task; thus it measures social processing broadly via self-related social trait processing.
Task is trait self-evaluation; it does not assess bonding/attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or social comparison in an affiliation/attachment sense.
No communicative exchange (e.g., face/voice/gaze, receptive/expressive signaling); participants rate trait adjectives about self.
Direct self-judgment about whether adjectives describe the self (agentic vs communal), i.e., self-knowledge/agency-related self-referential processing.
No judgments about other people’s traits/mental states; only self-evaluation of trait adjectives.
Contrast compares communal vs agentic traits during self-evaluation, which is a social-cognitive/self-referential trait processing task; therefore it falls under social processing broadly.
Although communal content relates to prosocial traits, the task does not measure attachment/bond formation or affiliative interaction; it is self-trait rating.
No communication signals or interaction are processed/produced; only adjective ratings.
Self-evaluation of communal vs agentic traits is explicitly about self-concept/self-knowledge.
Does not require representing others’ traits or mental states; contrast is within self-evaluation.
Contrast compares endorsement of others’ agentic vs communal evaluations of the self; this is social processing involving reflected appraisal/social feedback about the self.
Endorsing others’ evaluations is social feedback processing but not specifically attachment/affiliation bonding, kinship, or cooperation/competition.
No communicative cue processing (faces/voices/gaze) or production; stimuli are trait words and a purported rating context.
Participants judge agreement with others’ evaluation of themselves, which is self-knowledge/reflected self-processing.
Although framed as others’ opinions, the judgment is about the self (agreement with evaluation of self) rather than understanding others’ traits/mental states.
Contrast compares endorsement of others’ communal vs agentic evaluations of the self; reflects social feedback/reflected appraisal processing, a social-cognitive domain.
Not an attachment/affiliation bonding or cooperation/competition paradigm; it is agreement with others’ evaluation of self.
No facial/non-facial communication reception/production; task uses words and ratings.
Reflected self-evaluation (endorsement of others’ evaluation of oneself) is a self-related judgment task.
Does not involve reasoning about others’ mental states/traits; others are only a source of evaluation about the self.

Whole-brain regression of self-esteem with SA (agentic self-evaluation) vs fixation captures individual differences in neural response during a self-referential social trait judgment task; thus it measures social processing broadly.
Agentic self-evaluation and correlation with self-esteem are not specifically attachment/affiliation constructs.
No communication exchange/cue processing; it is internal self-trait evaluation.
SA vs fixation isolates self-evaluation of agentic traits; regression with self-esteem targets self-knowledge/agency-related self-processing.
No evaluation of others’ traits or mental states in this contrast; it is self-evaluation vs baseline.

PPI examines task-modulated connectivity during agentic self-evaluation (SA vs fixation) using dlPFC seed; still part of social processing because the underlying task is self-referential/social trait judgment.
Connectivity during agentic self-evaluation is not an affiliation/attachment task.
No communicative signal processing/production; PPI is driven by self-trait evaluation condition.
Connectivity changes are specifically tied to SA (self-evaluation) vs fixation, indexing neural systems supporting self-knowledge/agency judgments.
PPI does not involve representing others’ mental states/traits; condition is self-evaluation.

PPI examines task-modulated connectivity during agentic self-evaluation (SA vs fixation) using thalamus seed; because the task is self-referential social trait evaluation, it falls under social processing broadly.
Not an attachment/affiliation paradigm; examines connectivity during self-trait evaluation.
No receptive/expressive communication components; words-based self-evaluation drives the PPI.
Task-modulated thalamic connectivity is specific to agentic self-evaluation vs fixation, a Perception/Understanding of Self process.
No explicit processing of others’ traits/mental states; others are not the target in SA condition.

Participants performed an empathic accuracy task involving tracking another person’s emotional intensity in autobiographical videos; the contrast emotional>neutral targets social/emotion processing and mentalising broadly.
Task involves perceiving others’ emotions, not forming/assessing bonds, attachment, affiliation, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship cues (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

Stimuli are communicative autobiographical videos (speech/facial/non-facial cues) and participants decode socially relevant emotional information; emotional>neutral indexes processing of social communicative content.
Although participants continuously rate, the construct is not self-referential judgment/agency/self-knowledge; contrast is about processing others’ emotional content vs neutral.
Core demand is understanding another person’s emotional intensity (mental state) from dynamic cues; emotional>neutral measures enhanced processing of others’ affective states.
Neutral>emotional still derives from the same social video task and reflects differential processing during socially relevant (but emotionally neutral) person narratives versus emotional narratives.
No manipulation of bonding/attachment/affiliation; neutral videos describe bedrooms and do not probe relationship formation or attachment constructs.
Both conditions are communicative videos; the contrast isolates processing differences for neutral social communication versus emotional social communication.
Contrast does not require explicit self-evaluation or self-knowledge/agency; any default-mode/self-referential activity is incidental rather than task construct.
Participants still attend to and rate the target (other person) even in neutral clips; the contrast reflects processing of others’ states/cues (low emotional intensity) versus emotional narratives.
Parametric modulation by empathic accuracy (Z-EA) directly indexes variability in social-cognitive performance during the empathic accuracy task.
Z-EA reflects accuracy in tracking others’ emotions, not affiliation/attachment bonding or relationship evaluation.
Empathic accuracy depends on decoding communicative cues in the targets’ videos; modulation by Z-EA reflects effectiveness of processing social-communicative signals.
Regressor reflects agreement with target’s ratings (other-focused accuracy), not self-referential judgments or agency/self-knowledge constructs.
Z-EA quantifies how well participants infer/track the target’s emotional intensity over time—an ‘understanding mental states’ measure about others.
Negative modulation by empathic accuracy is still a social-processing effect within an empathic accuracy/mentalising task.
No affiliation/attachment construct is manipulated; negative correlations with Z-EA do not imply bonding/attachment processing.
Even inverse relationships with Z-EA reflect how social-communicative cue processing relates to performance on understanding targets’ emotions.

Although regions like paracingulate/DMN may relate to self-referential processing, this analysis is not designed to measure self-knowledge/agency; it is performance modulation on an other-focused task.
Z-EA is a measure of inferring others’ emotional state; negative modulation indicates reduced activation with better other-understanding but remains within perception/understanding of others.
Trial-by-trial/time-varying correlation between BOLD and perceived emotional intensity during social videos reflects dynamic social-emotional processing.
Ratings track perceived emotional intensity of a target, not relationship bonding/attachment or affiliation behaviors.
Continuous ratings are driven by decoding ongoing communicative signals (speech, facial/voice prosody) in videos; positive coupling reflects social communication processing.
Regressor is participant’s perception of the target’s emotional intensity (other-focused), not self state/trait judgments; affect sharing was queried post-clip but not modeled here.
Directly measures neural tracking of another person’s emotional intensity over time (understanding mental states/action/affect perception of others).

Negative coupling with perceived emotional intensity occurs during a social-emotion perception task and reflects social processing dynamics (e.g., DMN suppression with higher other-emotion intensity).
No attachment/affiliation manipulation; negative correlations do not index bonding or relational closeness.
Inverse relationships with intensity still relate to processing socially communicated emotional information in the videos (receptive social communication).

Although negative effects appear in PCC/precuneus often linked to self-referential processing, the modeled variable is perception of the other’s emotion, not explicit self-judgment; thus does not meet self construct criteria.
The parametric regressor is perceived emotional intensity of the target; negative coupling still reflects neural modulation by others’ emotional state perception.
