This table compiles peak MNI coordinates from prior 'general semantics' studies; it is not derived from a social task/contrast and does not measure social processing (it is about semantic processing broadly across categories).
No manipulation of affiliation/attachment (bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, etc.); coordinates reflect general semantic processing literature.
Not a social communication task/contrast; table summarizes general semantic peaks rather than facial/nonfacial communication processing.
No self-referential judgment or self-knowledge/agency component; coordinates are from general semantic literature.
Not explicitly about perceiving/understanding others (traits/mental states); it is general semantics peaks across categories.
This table compiles peak coordinates from face-selective ATL studies; face perception/recognition is a core social-information domain and constitutes social processing broadly.
Face-selective responses do not specifically index affiliation/attachment or bonding (no loved-one/relationship manipulation).
Face processing/recognition supports receptive facial communication (a subcomponent of social communication). Face-selective contrasts are therefore relevant to social communication.
No self-referential or self-knowledge task; focus is on faces/others.
Recognizing/processing faces is part of perceiving others (animacy/person perception) and supports understanding others’ identity and social cues.

Contrast explicitly isolates socially relevant person knowledge (faces+spoken names of famous people) relative to non-social semantic knowledge (landmarks). This measures social processing (social semantics/person knowledge).
Although stimuli are people, the task is a semantic/nationality judgment about famous people vs landmarks; it does not assess bonding/attachment or relationship-related affiliation.
Includes processing of faces and person identity information (receptive facial communication/person recognition), contrasted against non-social semantics.
No self-related judgments or self-knowledge/agency manipulation; stimuli are external (people/landmarks).
Processing famous people (faces and names) engages perception/representation of others (person identity/animacy) relative to non-social items.

This is the reverse contrast (landmarks > people) within a task that includes a social semantic condition; it still measures differential processing as a function of social (people) vs non-social semantic content, thus indexing social processing dimensionally.
Does not probe affiliation/attachment; it is non-social > social semantic content.

Because the contrast is defined relative to a face/person condition, it still pertains to the social-communication/person-recognition domain (showing regions more engaged by non-social than social stimuli).
No self-referential processing.
Contrast is anchored on processing others (people) vs non-social items, thus still part of the perception-of-others construct dimensionally (non-social greater than social).

Contrast isolates person-related semantic knowledge (famous faces + written names) relative to non-social semantic association (Camel and Cactus). This is a social vs non-social semantic manipulation.
No attachment/affiliation manipulation (not loved ones/close relationships; just famous people).
Includes face processing and person identity recognition (receptive facial/non-facial person cues) compared to non-social semantics, aligning with social communication reception aspects.
No self-knowledge/agency judgment; task concerns others vs objects/animals.
Famous person identification/occupation matching from faces/names involves representations about others (identity/traits/biographical knowledge) relative to non-social items.

Reverse contrast (non-social Camel and Cactus > famous people) is still part of the social vs non-social semantic comparison and thus measures the social-processing dimension by identifying regions more active for non-social semantics than social/person knowledge.
No affiliation/attachment content; it emphasizes non-social semantics.
Although direction is non-social > social, the contrast is defined with respect to a person/face condition; thus it still pertains to social communication/person-perception processing differences.
No self-related processing component.
Anchored on person knowledge (others) vs non-social items; identifies areas less engaged by others relative to non-social, still within perception-of-others dimension.
Contrast compares socially relevant concept words vs non-social abstract words during synonym judgments, directly measuring processing of social conceptual content.
Socially relevant words are not specifically about bonding/attachment/cooperation; contrast targets social semantics broadly rather than affiliation/attachment.
Task is semantic synonym judgment on social vs non-social abstract words; it does not involve communicative signal processing (faces/gaze/prosody) or interactive communication demands.
No self-referential judgments; stimuli are generic concept words.

Although labeled 'social concept words', they are not specifically about perceiving/mentalizing about other agents (e.g., intentions/emotions of a person); rather they are abstract social trait/behavior concepts, so this is better captured by broad social processing than perception-of-others as defined.

Reverse contrast (non-social abstract words > social concept words) is still a direct comparison along the social semantic dimension, identifying regions more engaged by non-social than social conceptual content.
Does not probe affiliation/attachment; it emphasizes non-social abstract semantics.
No explicit communicative signal processing; lexical-semantic task only.
No self-processing manipulation.
Not a task requiring perception/mental state reasoning about others; it is non-social abstract semantics greater than social abstract semantics.

Parametric modulation of BOLD during a mind-perception (internal state attribution) task using trial-by-trial mind ratings. This is a social-cognitive task directly measuring social processing (mentalizing/animacy/intentional stance).
Task involves judging whether an agent has internal states; it does not assess bonding, attachment, affiliation, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship constructs.

Although stimuli are faces, the contrast is not about communicative signal exchange (e.g., gaze following, facial affect recognition) but about attributing internal states/mind to agents. No reception/production of communicative cues is being tested as the primary construct in this analysis.
No self-referential judgments, self-traits, agency about self, or self-knowledge are measured; ratings are about the agents (others).

Mind-rating parametric regressor indexes trialwise attribution of internal states/animacy to agents (understanding others' mental states / animacy perception), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.

Parametric modulation of BOLD during mind-perception task weighted by later gaze-cueing performance with the same agents. Because the modulation reflects sensitivity to a social attention/interaction outcome (gaze cueing) linked to social cues (eye gaze), it measures social processing broadly.
Gaze cueing and mind perception do not involve affiliative bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship evaluation.

Parametric regressor is based on gaze-cueing effects, a classic measure of gaze following/social attention to communicative eye-gaze cues (receptive nonverbal/facial communication). Thus the analysis indexes neural activity related to processing communicative gaze signals (via performance weights).
No self-related evaluation or self-agency construct is measured; modulation is by behavior to others' gaze cues, not self-knowledge.

Gaze cueing depends on perceiving and interpreting another agent’s gaze direction/intentionality; weighting by gaze-cueing performance ties activation to perception/understanding of others’ actions and inferred intentions (action perception/mental state understanding).

Task involves recognizing and classifying facial emotions (own vs unknown child), which is inherently social and measures processing of social cues (facial affect). Contrast happy-own>neutral-own indexes neural responses to socially relevant emotional signals.

Stimuli are the mother’s own child (attachment figure) and contrast examines response to the child’s happy expression vs neutral, engaging parent–child bonding/affiliative processing (reward/attachment-related salience of own child cues).
Paradigm is receptive facial communication (decoding emotional expression). Happy vs neutral faces of own child directly measure reception/recognition of facial affect as social communication.

No explicit self-referential judgment, self-trait evaluation, agency, or introspective appraisal; mothers classify others’ facial emotions. Although 'own child' is personally relevant, the task does not require processing the self.

Contrast measures perception/understanding of another person’s emotional state (child’s happiness vs neutral) via facial affect recognition, aligning with understanding mental states/emotion perception of others.

Group-specific (ELM) happy-own>neutral-own effect in a facial emotion recognition task; still measures neural processing of social-emotional cues, with masking highlighting ELM>CON differences but underlying contrast remains social processing.

Uses mother’s own child stimuli; contrast probes differential processing of affiliative positive cues (child happiness) within attachment context, and the mask isolates ELM-specific enhancement relative to controls.
Receptive facial communication: decoding child facial emotion (happy vs neutral). Masking by group×emotion does not change that the measured construct is facial affect recognition.
No self-focused appraisal or self-knowledge/agency component; processing is directed at the child’s facial emotion. Group comparisons do not introduce self-perception measurement.
Measures perception of another’s emotional state (own child) and associated mentalizing-related processing (e.g., STS/precuneus reported), fitting perception/understanding of others.

The task requires recalling and re-experiencing relationship episodes involving the self (vs viewing neutral control pictures), engaging social-cognitive processing about interpersonal interactions along with autobiographical/social memory.

Episodes are drawn from close relationship experiences with significant others and recurrent interpersonal behavior patterns; recalling formative relationship episodes taps relational/attachment-relevant processing even though not a direct loved-one vs stranger contrast.

Although stimuli depict interpersonal situations, the contrast primarily targets autobiographical recall/self-relevant relationship reflection rather than communication behaviors (e.g., facial affect recognition, gaze, communicative exchange) or explicit receptive/productive social communication judgments.

Self-relevant condition explicitly requires recalling one's own formative relationship episodes and re-experiencing associated feelings (arousal/valence), directly engaging self-referential processing and self-knowledge/awareness relative to control viewing.

This specific contrast is self-relevant > control and does not require reasoning about others’ mental states as a primary target; the 'other' condition would better index perception/understanding of others.

Impression-formation task involves evaluating faces varying in race and socioeconomic status; the PLS LV reflects neural coactivation during social evaluation/impression formation, a core social-processing paradigm.

Although participants form impressions, the task does not measure bonding/attachment, close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts; it is evaluation of unfamiliar faces.

The task involves passive viewing/impression formation of faces, not communicative exchange or receptive/productive communication processes (e.g., gaze following, expression recognition as an explicit communication measure) nor contrasts targeting communication.

No self-referential judgments or explicit introspection/self-knowledge/agency task component is manipulated in the contrast; EMS is an individual-difference regressor but the measured neural patterns are during other-person impression formation.

Participants form impressions of other people from faces (race/status cues), engaging person perception and social cognition/mentalizing-related processing; the LV indexes EMS-related modulation of coactivation during evaluating others.

Same impression-formation face-evaluation task; this LV/contrast captures EMS-related increased coactivation during social evaluation of targets varying by race/status, thus measuring social processing.
No manipulation/measurement of attachment or affiliative bonding; stimuli are unfamiliar faces and responses are impression-formation, not relationship/affiliation processes.
Not a social communication task/contrast; no communicative signals are exchanged or explicitly processed as communication outcomes.
Does not require self-referential evaluation; EMS is a trait covariate rather than a self-perception task contrast.
Impression formation about others from faces (person evaluation) directly targets perception/understanding of others.

Control task involves evaluating faces (white actors/models) for attractiveness/likeability; this is a social evaluation/person-perception task and the PLS LV reflects neural coactivation during these social judgments.
Attractiveness/likeability ratings of unfamiliar faces do not measure attachment bonds or affiliative relationship formation (no loved-one/close-other, cooperation, or bonding contrast).
Task is explicit rating, not communication; does not assess receptive/productive social communication processes as defined.
No self-judgment or self-knowledge component; activity relates to evaluating others' faces.
Explicit judgments about other people’s faces (attractiveness/likeability) are person perception/evaluation, fitting perception/understanding of others.
Control task PLS LV reflects EMS-related increased coactivation during face evaluations (attractiveness/likeability), which are social evaluative processes.
No attachment/affiliation bonding manipulation; ratings of unfamiliar actors/models are not attachment measures.
Does not involve communicative exchange or explicit communication perception/production contrasts.
Not a self-referential task; individual difference EMS does not make the contrast self-perception.
Participants evaluate others’ faces for attractiveness/likeability; this is directly about perceiving/judging others.

Localizer-based responses to faces/voices with emotional expressions and subsequent ROI analyses index processing of socially relevant cues (faces/voices), i.e., social information processing.
Tasks involve perceptual processing of emotional faces/voices and gender discrimination, not bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-focused evaluation.
Analyses involve reception/recognition of facial and vocal emotional signals (socially communicative cues) across modalities, central to receptive social communication.
No self-referential judgments, self-knowledge, or agency processing; stimuli concern others’ expressions and an orthogonal gender task.
Processing and integration of others’ emotional expressions from faces/voices constitutes perception/understanding of others’ affective states.
Bimodal vs unimodal face/voice contrasts probe multisensory integration of emotional expressions—core social information processing.
Contrast does not assess affiliative bonding/attachment or relationship evaluation; it is perceptual integration of emotion cues.
Measures neural integration of communicative facial and vocal emotion signals (receptive social communication).
No self-processing component; stimuli and contrast concern processing others’ expressions across modalities.
Directly targets perception of others’ emotional expressions via face/voice integration (fearful/neutral).
Incongruent>congruent audiovisual emotion expressions engages processing of social signals and conflict in social cue integration, still within social processing domain.
Congruency manipulation of emotion cues is not about affiliation/attachment, bonding, or relationship valuation.
Assesses sensitivity to congruency of facial and vocal emotional communication signals (receptive social communication).
Does not involve self-referential processing, agency, or self-knowledge; focuses on externally presented social cues.
Requires evaluating and integrating others’ emotional expressions; incongruency pertains to interpreting others’ affective state signals.

Task involves judging others' trustworthiness from faces and processing feedback about others' traits (social evaluation/learning). Contrast (Younger > older) during feedback still measures social processing differences across groups.

Although trustworthiness is socially relevant, the task does not directly measure affiliation/attachment bonds or cooperative interaction with partners; it is impression/trait learning rather than attachment or relationship bonding.
No communicative exchange (receptive/expressive) is measured; faces are used as stimuli for trait judgment, not communication signals like emotion recognition or gaze/expressive interaction.
Contrast is not about self-referential judgments or self-knowledge/agency; participants evaluate others and receive correctness feedback, but not asked to reflect on self traits/states.
Participants infer others' trait (cooperative vs selfish) and update impressions based on feedback; this is reasoning about others' stable characteristics (social cognition/mentalizing-related).
Congruent vs incongruent feedback about others' true trustworthiness during social impression updating is a social processing contrast.
Feedback congruency does not operationalize affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding; it is learning/evaluation of strangers' trustworthiness.
Contrast concerns feedback learning about traits, not perception/production of communicative signals (e.g., emotion/gaze) or interaction.
Not self-referential; focuses on processing feedback about judgments of others, without explicit self-related appraisal.
Directly contrasts processing of information about others' traits that confirms vs contradicts prior impression; core 'understanding others' construct.
Age×feedback interaction during feedback about others' trustworthiness reflects differential social learning/evaluation across age groups.
Interaction reflects reward-related learning signals to correctness feedback, not affiliative bonding/attachment processes.
No communicative exchange measured; interaction pertains to reward/learning from trait feedback.
Although feedback is about one's judgment accuracy, the modeled effect is processing of feedback about others' traits; not explicit self-perception task.
Interaction is driven by how incongruent vs congruent information about others' trustworthiness is processed; this is understanding others' traits.
Reward-related regions contrast (Younger > older) during social feedback about others' trustworthiness still indexes social processing differences across groups.
Not measuring attachment/affiliative bonding; feedback pertains to trait accuracy rather than relationship formation.
No social communication behavior/signals are being exchanged or evaluated; it is trait-learning feedback.
No explicit self-referential processing; contrast is group difference in feedback responses in reward-related areas.
Participants process correctness feedback about others being cooperative/selfish; this is evaluating others' traits.
Congruent > incongruent feedback in reward-related regions during trustworthiness learning is a social processing contrast (social evaluation/learning context).
Congruency effects do not test affiliative/attachment processes; no close relationship or bonding manipulation.
No communicative signal processing contrast; instead reward/learning response to feedback about traits.
Not self-judgment; focuses on processing feedback about others' trustworthiness (even if self-performance is implied).
Contrast reflects differential processing of trait-confirming vs trait-contradicting information about other people (cooperator/cheater).

Task is an interactive joint-action paradigm (leading/following improvised bimanual partnered movements with physical interaction). Although primarily motor, it explicitly involves social interaction/role coordination, which constitutes social processing in broad terms.
No manipulation or measurement of bonding, attachment, cooperation/competition, kinship, or relationship formation; task is role-based motor coordination with an experimenter.

Leading/following requires exchanging socially relevant information via haptic cues (non-verbal, non-facial communication) to coordinate joint movement roles; the analysis includes both roles vs rest, capturing this interactive communicative context.

Conjunction (Leading>Rest ∩ Following>Rest) includes conditions requiring self-generated motor control/monitoring (especially in leading) and role performance; these involve agency/self-monitoring components of self-perception within the task context.

Following (part of the conjunction) requires attending to and interpreting partner-provided movement cues (action perception/inferring intentions), and the joint task inherently involves representing the other’s actions.
Same joint interactive leading/following task; conjunction in followers reflects social role-based interaction and coordination, meeting broad social processing criteria.
No affiliation/attachment construct is manipulated or contrasted; no loved-one/stranger, bonding, or cooperative reward context.
Followers perform nonverbal, haptic information exchange with partner as part of role coordination; conjunction captures this communicative interaction.
Role enactment requires awareness/monitoring of one’s own actions and agency (even in following, matching/complementing movements), which falls under self-perception in this context.
Following emphasizes interpreting partner’s movement cues (action perception/mental state inference); even the conjunction includes following blocks that require other-focused processing.
Contrast Leading>Following (and reported network differences) is explicitly about social roles in interaction; it measures differential processing of leader vs follower roles during joint action.
Contrast tests role (leader vs follower) demands, not attachment, affiliation, bonding, or relationship valuation.
Leading vs following changes directionality/production vs reception of nonverbal (haptic) communicative signals used to coordinate action; thus the contrast measures social communication components.
Leading emphasizes agency/self-initiation and self-monitoring relative to following; the contrast is designed to isolate leader-related self-generated action processes.

Following (opposite side of the contrast) relies more on perceiving/interpreting partner actions/intentions; the bidirectional role contrast inherently indexes other-related processing differences (even if this table entry is Leading>Following).
Contrast Following>Leading targets follower role processing in an interactive joint task; this is social-role-based processing.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation or outcome; it is role coordination rather than bonding/cooperation evaluation.
Following involves reception/interpretation of partner-provided haptic cues (receptive non-facial communication) more than leading; the contrast measures this communicative aspect.
Even though following is other-oriented, it still involves self-monitoring and adjusting one’s own actions; moreover, the bidirectional role contrast includes self/agency differences across roles.
Following>Leading is explicitly expected to engage mentalizing/action understanding regions (e.g., TPJ, pSTS, PCC), reflecting perception/understanding of others’ actions/intentions.

Regression links differential leader-vs-follower role activation (Leading>Following) to leader expertise during an interactive joint task; still measures social-role processing modulated by expertise.
Covariate is leader skill (expertise), not attachment/affiliation; no bonding-related contrasts.
Leader skill reflects production of communicative movement cues to a partner; regression on Leading>Following captures variation in this nonverbal social communication component with expertise.
Leader expertise is tied to agency/self-initiated action planning; regression on Leading>Following indexes self-related (agency) components varying with skill.

Although primarily leader/agency-related, leading in joint action still requires modeling partner’s responses; the role contrast in a social interaction context is within social cognition domain (broad other-related component present).
Deactivations/regression effects are still derived from the social-role contrast (Leading vs Following) with leader skill; thus within social processing domain.
No attachment/affiliation variable or manipulation.
Even when examining negative associations/deactivations, the construct remains social communication via leading/following role signaling in joint action.
Leader-skill-related decreases in role-contrast betas still pertain to self/agency processes in leading vs following.

Because the underlying contrast is between interacting roles, changes (including deactivations) can reflect relative weighting of other-focused vs self-focused processing across roles; thus still fits perception/understanding of others at the task level.
Regression links role contrast (Leading vs Following) to follower expertise; directly targets social-role processing in an interactive context.
Follower skill is expertise, not affiliation/attachment; no bonding or relationship comparison.
Follower expertise reflects receptive nonverbal (haptic) communication and responsiveness to partner cues; regression on role contrast captures this.
Following requires monitoring and adjusting one’s own actions; the role contrast with follower skill includes self-related control/agency differences as participants alternate roles.

Follower-skill regression highlights classic other-understanding regions (mPFC, TPJ, pSTS, PCC) consistent with understanding others’ actions/intentions; directly satisfies perception/understanding of others.

Iterated Prisoner's Dilemma is a dyadic social interaction/cooperation task; CC outcomes index processing of positive social interaction feedback, which is social processing.
CC (reciprocated cooperation) reflects affiliative/reciprocal cooperation and positive social exchange during an interaction game, fitting cooperation/affiliation constructs.

Although interactive, the contrast targets outcome-related reward/salience of reciprocated cooperation rather than communicative signal reception/production (e.g., facial affect recognition, gaze, explicit message exchange).
Contrast is not primarily about self-referential judgment/agency/self-knowledge; it is about neural response to social outcome feedback (partner reciprocation).
CC outcome requires interpreting the partner's cooperative behavior (other's action/intent in reciprocal interaction), engaging understanding of others in a social exchange.
Same PD dyadic social cooperation task; CC outcomes measure neural response to positive social interaction feedback in women.
Reciprocated cooperation operationalizes affiliative/reciprocal positive interaction within cooperation task.
No explicit social communication construct measured (no facial communication/gaze/linguistic exchange contrasts); outcome feedback is the focus.
Not a self-evaluation or agency contrast; focuses on outcome of interaction with partner.
Involves processing partner's reciprocation (other's cooperative action), relevant to representing others’ behavior/intent in interaction.
PD game is a social interaction task; CD (unreciprocated cooperation) measures response to negative social interaction feedback (betrayal/defection), within social processing.

Unreciprocated cooperation indexes breakdown/violation of cooperative affiliation in a cooperation/competition paradigm, still within affiliation/attachment-related processing of social bond/cooperation.
Contrast pertains to outcome evaluation of cooperation vs defection rather than communication reception/production cues.
Does not require explicit self-referential appraisal; primarily evaluates partner's defection outcome.
CD requires interpreting partner’s defection (other’s action/intent), relevant to understanding others’ behavior/mental states during interaction.
Same PD social interaction task; CD outcomes in women measure neural response to negative social interaction feedback.
Processing unreciprocated cooperation (partner defects) within a cooperation/competition task relates to affiliative reciprocity and its violation.
No communicative signaling/recognition contrast; outcome feedback drives activation.
Not centered on self-knowledge/agency judgments; centers on partner response to participant cooperation.
Involves representing the partner's defection behavior (other’s action/intent) in a social exchange.

Taylor Aggression Paradigm involves social provocation by an ostensible opponent and retaliatory decisions; contrast H>L during feedback indexes processing of socially delivered provocation.
Task is competitive/reactive aggression, not focused on bonding, attachment, or positive affiliative interactions; H>L feedback does not measure affiliation/attachment.
No explicit communication cue processing (e.g., faces, voices, gestures) is isolated; feedback is monetary/provocation information rather than receptive/expressive communication contrast.
Contrast targets response to opponent provocation feedback, not self-referential appraisal, agency judgments, or self-knowledge.
High vs low provocation feedback reflects evaluation of another agent’s (opponent’s) harmful intent/behavior, engaging representations about others’ actions and likely mental states.
Same socially interactive provocation context; L>H during feedback indexes differential processing of socially delivered (low) provocation vs high.
Low provocation is not an affiliative/attachment condition; still within competitive aggression task without bonding construct.
Does not isolate communication reception/production; contrast is provocation magnitude in monetary feedback.
Not a self-perception/agency contrast; reflects processing of opponent feedback magnitude.
Feedback about opponent’s punitive action requires interpreting others’ behavior; L>H captures differential other-action evaluation.
Decision phase after social provocation involves selecting punishment toward opponent; H>L decision captures social decision-making in response to provocation.
Decision to retaliate is not measuring attachment/affiliation or bonding; no loved-one/relationship manipulation.
No communicative signal processing; decision is monetary punishment selection, not communication exchange.
Although decision reflects participant action, the contrast is driven by provocation level rather than explicit self-referential judgment or agency/self-knowledge task.
Decision after high vs low provocation depends on evaluating opponent’s prior behavior/intent; engages understanding of others in a social interaction.
L>H during decision still within social interaction/retaliation context, indexing social decision processes as a function of provocation.
Not an attachment/affiliation manipulation; low provocation does not equal affiliative bonding.
Decision contrast does not involve communication reception/production measures.
No explicit self-evaluation or self-knowledge/agency contrast; it is provocation-modulated retaliation decision.
Decision depends on appraisal of opponent behavior; L>H reflects changes in other-related evaluation underlying retaliation.
Treatment×genotype interaction in cuneus during TAP decision period reflects modulation of neural responses within a social provocation/retaliation task, thus measuring social processing differences.
Interaction pertains to reactive aggression/attention to provocation, not affiliative bonding or attachment constructs.
No communicative cue processing is isolated; interaction is on provocation-related decision activity.
Interaction is not derived from self-referential or agency/self-knowledge judgments; it is a group interaction effect on provocation-related decision activation.
Because the decision period is contingent on opponent’s prior provocation, the interaction effect reflects differential processing of another agent’s behavior/intent within social exchange.

Contrast compares cooperative vs competitive social exchange during a dyadic interactive game (hyperscanning). This directly probes social interaction processes and partner-dependent responses (iBBD).

Cooperation (helping partner) vs competition (hindering) indexes affiliative/prosocial vs antagonistic social interaction, capturing bonding/affiliative dimension of social exchange even without close-relationship cues.

Task involves interactive behavior but not specifically communicative signal exchange (e.g., facial/vocal/gaze/explicit messaging); contrast is about goal structure (cooperate vs compete) rather than communication modality or reception/production of communicative cues.
Contrast does not require explicit self-reflection, self-knowledge, or agency judgments about oneself; it models neural responses to partner’s moves differing by cooperative/competitive context.

Participants must monitor and interpret partner’s actions (and likely intentions) to respond in the game; contrast isolates how brain responses to partner behavior differ under cooperation vs competition (other-action/mental-state processing).
Competition vs cooperation during real-time dyadic interaction is a social-processing contrast examining partner-dependent neural responses.
Opposes antagonistic/competitive exchange against affiliative/cooperative exchange, directly targeting the affiliation vs non-affiliation dimension of social interaction.
Although interactive, the contrast is not about communicative cue exchange (facial/vocal/gaze) or explicit communication processes; it manipulates goal structure (compete vs cooperate).
No explicit self-evaluation/agency/self-referential judgment is contrasted; focus is on differential reactivity to partner moves across social goals.
Competitive contexts increase need to track/predict opponent behavior; contrast captures other-action/intent processing differences between competition and cooperation.
CN vs TB contrasts interaction structure in a two-person social exchange; measures how partner-dependent neural responses differ across forms of real-time interaction.
Interaction structure (concurrent vs turn-based) does not specifically index affiliative bonding/prosociality; it changes temporal coordination demands irrespective of affiliative content.
Manipulation is timing/structure of coordinated action rather than communication reception/production; no explicit communicative cues are targeted by the contrast.
CN vs TB does not entail self-reflection or self-knowledge; primarily alters coordination and planning demands in response to partner actions.

Both CN and TB require monitoring the partner’s actions; CN particularly increases real-time inference/prediction of partner behavior. Thus contrast pertains to processing others’ actions/mental states under different interaction dynamics.
Goal-by-interaction contrast (difference of cooperation–competition between TB and CN) examines how social exchange dimensions modulate partner-dependent brain responses, i.e., social processing.
This interaction tests how the affiliative/prosocial dimension (cooperate vs compete) differs across interaction structure, still centrally about cooperation/competition effects.
Not a communication-specific manipulation; it is about cooperative/competitive goal differences across concurrent vs turn-based structure.
Does not directly assess self-referential processing; models reactivity to partner moves across social-goal and interaction-structure factors.
The interaction reflects how processing/prediction of partner actions differs depending on whether interaction is concurrent or turn-based and whether partner is helper/hinderer (cooperate/compete).
Role-by-goal contrast compares Builders vs Others for the cooperation–competition effect, within an interactive dyadic task; this is social processing of partner-dependent behavior.
Builders’ differential responses to cooperative vs competitive partner behavior (relative to Others) still reflects affiliative/prosocial vs antagonistic dynamics modulated by role.
Although roles differ, the contrast is not about communicative cue production/reception; it is about social goal effects by task role.
Role differences here pertain to task position (Builder vs Other) rather than explicit self-related judgments or agency attribution; primary construct is partner-action reactivity.
Both roles require interpreting partner’s token placements; contrast isolates role-dependent differences in processing others’ actions under cooperation vs competition.
Reverse role-by-goal contrast (Others vs Builders for cooperation–competition effect) is still within dyadic social interaction and measures social processing of partner-dependent behavior.
Captures how affiliative/prosocial vs competitive dynamics (cooperate–compete) are expressed differently when acting as the Other compared with Builder.
Not focused on communication channels or explicit communicative behavior; it is about goal structure effects by role.
Does not require explicit self-referential evaluation; it contrasts role-dependent neural responses to partner actions across cooperative vs competitive contexts.

As the Other (helper/hinderer/observer), participants must track the Builder’s actions; contrast captures differences in other-action/intent processing across cooperation vs competition relative to Builder role.

Contrast LIVE > REPLAY during mutual eye gaze (real-time vs delayed) directly targets social interaction/eye contact, a social processing task involving interpreting and responding to a partner’s gaze/blink cues.

Task manipulates real-time reciprocity in eye contact but does not assess bonding/attachment, relationship formation, love/kinship, or cooperative/competitive affiliation outcomes; partners are strangers and no attachment construct is contrasted.
Eye contact/mutual gaze is a core social communication behavior; LIVE > REPLAY isolates on-line bidirectional exchange of facial/eye cues (receptive/interactive facial communication).

Although authors discuss self-awareness (ACC/AIC), the activation contrast is not a self-referential judgment/agency task; it manipulates interaction timing rather than explicit self-focused appraisal.

Participants attend to and interpret partner-related cues (gaze/blinks) and are instructed to think about what the partner is thinking/feeling; LIVE > REPLAY increases demands on perceiving others’ actions/mental states via real-time contingency.
gPPI examines task-modulated effective connectivity (LIVE vs REPLAY) during mutual gaze; it measures neural coupling changes associated with real-time social interaction.
Connectivity differences are driven by real-time interaction vs delay, not by attachment/affiliative bonding manipulations or relationship-valued targets (e.g., loved one).
Effective connectivity from ACC to dAIC is compared between LIVE and REPLAY while participants engage in eye contact; this is modulation linked to ongoing social communicative exchange through gaze.
Despite interpretation in terms of self-awareness networks, the analysis does not involve explicit self-monitoring/agency/self-knowledge contrasts; it is primarily about interaction mode.
During LIVE mutual gaze, participants continuously process partner’s facial/eye actions; task-dependent connectivity reflects processing of other-related cues/contingency in interaction.
Interbrain synchronization LIVE > REPLAY directly quantifies dyadic neural coupling during real-time social interaction (mutual gaze), a social processing measure at the pair level.
Neural synchrony is assessed for real-time interaction but not for affiliative bonding/attachment constructs; dyads are strangers and no attachment-relevant comparison is made.
Interbrain synchrony during LIVE mutual gaze indexes coordinated processing in a communicative exchange (eye contact/blink timing as communication cues).
The synchrony analysis does not isolate self-referential/agency processing; it measures between-brain coupling in visual regions during interaction.

Enhanced synchrony in bilateral middle occipital gyrus during LIVE likely reflects shared processing of partner’s visual actions (blink/gaze) and action perception mechanisms tied to perceiving the other in real time.

Face Processing Task using fearful vs neutral human faces (F>N, N>F) is an explicitly social/emotional stimulus paradigm assessing socioemotional processing (canonical socioemotional network: TPJ, insula, mPFC, amygdala). Thus the contrast measures social processing broadly.
Task involves viewing and rating emotional faces; it does not manipulate affiliation/attachment, bonding, loved-one vs stranger, kinship, or relationship formation processes.
Perception of facial expressions (fearful vs neutral) constitutes receptive social communication (facial affect recognition/processing). Contrasts reflect processing of facial social cues.

Participants explicitly rate 'how negative it made them feel' after each face, engaging introspection/self-monitoring of current affect; N>F showing mPFC is consistent with internal mentation. Thus the analysis includes self-perception components.

Viewing emotional faces requires perceiving and interpreting others' emotional states; TPJ/STS involvement supports understanding others. Fearful vs neutral contrasts index perception/understanding of others' affect.

Regression of empathy (TEQ) onto task contrasts during emotional face processing tests how trait empathy modulates socioemotional processing during a social task, meeting broad social processing criteria.
Trait empathy modulation during face viewing does not operationalize affiliation/attachment or bonding/relationship manipulations.
Outcome reflects modulation of receptive facial communication processing (fearful vs neutral faces) by empathy; TPJ effects relate to processing social cues from faces.
Task includes self-affect ratings; empathy-related modulation during the stimulus+rating window can reflect self-referential affective experience while processing social stimuli.
Empathy is intrinsically about understanding others; regression identifies neural modulation of processing others' emotional expressions (fearful faces) by empathy trait.
Regression of trait anxiety (STAI) onto fearful/neutral face processing examines individual-difference modulation of socioemotional processing during a social task.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation; anxiety modulation is not specific to bonding or relationship processes.
Although anxiety is not a communication construct, the dependent measure is processing of facial emotional cues (receptive social communication) and its modulation by anxiety.
Participants introspectively rate their own negative affect; anxiety-related differences (e.g., insula/mPFC carry-over) relate to self-experienced affect/interoception during the task.
Anxiety modulates processing of others' emotional faces (fearful/neutral), which is perception/understanding of others' affective states conveyed by facial expressions.
Regression of worry (PSWQ) onto social-emotional face processing contrasts assesses modulation of socioemotional processing within a canonical social network (e.g., mPFC).
Worry modulation during face viewing does not involve affiliation/attachment or bonding paradigms.
Dependent variable remains receptive processing of facial emotional signals (fearful vs neutral faces), a social-communication cue-processing task, with worry as a moderator.
Task requires rating one's own emotional reaction; worry-related mPFC modulation (especially N>F) aligns with internal mentation/self-focused evaluation during/after social stimuli.
Participants perceive others' emotional expressions; worry-related modulation occurs while processing those expressions, qualifying as perception/understanding of others within a social task.
Regression of rumination (RRS) onto fearful/neutral face processing evaluates individual-difference modulation of socioemotional processing during a social face task, engaging TPJ/insula/mPFC.
Rumination effects in this paradigm are not tied to affiliation/attachment or relationship/bonding manipulations.

The task is receptive facial communication (processing emotional faces). Rumination-related modulation of TPJ/insula/mPFC during N>F still reflects altered processing of facial social cues and their aftermath.
Rumination is an internally generated, self-focused process; combined with explicit self-affect ratings, the analysis captures self-perception/self-knowledge components (mPFC, insula interoception).
Rumination modulates how participants process others' emotional expressions (fearful/neutral faces) and mentalizing-related regions (TPJ), fitting perception/understanding of others.

Cyberball social exclusion is an explicitly social interaction/ostracism paradigm; contrast tests how emotional support modulates neural response to exclusion across runs, i.e., social processing of exclusion.

Although the manipulation involves receiving support from a friend, the contrast is not an affiliation/attachment construct comparison (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding/cooperation) but modulation of exclusion-related distress across runs.
No communicative signal processing contrast is modeled (no facial/voice/gaze/message comprehension contrast); the tested effect is exclusion run1 vs run2 differences under emotional touch support.
While exclusion induces self-relevant affect, the contrast does not require self-judgment/trait/agency evaluation; it tests neural change to exclusion after support.

Not a mentalizing/other-state reasoning contrast; emotional support analysis focused on affective network (e.g., anterior insula) during exclusion across runs, not explicitly assessing others’ mental states.
Cyberball exclusion is a social interaction/ostracism task; this contrast tests how appraisal support modulates exclusion-related processing across runs.
Contrast does not isolate affiliative bonding/attachment representations; it examines exclusion processing changes after informational/appraisal support.

Although appraisal support is delivered via text, the fMRI contrast is not message processing vs control; it is exclusion run1>run2 modulation, thus not directly measuring social communication processes.
No explicit self-reflection/self-knowledge/agency judgment is contrasted; effect reflects change in exclusion-related response after support.

Appraisal support aims to re-interpret others’ relationship/intentions (e.g., ‘these two players are friends’), and effects observed in TPJ (ToM network) indicate modulation of reasoning about others during exclusion across runs.
Contrast examines appraisal-support-related increase in neural response to social exclusion across runs in a cyberball paradigm, a core social processing task.
Not an attachment/affiliation contrast; increased subACC response reflects affective reaction to exclusion after appraisal support, not bonding/attachment processing per se.
Not a communication processing contrast (no explicit comparison of communicative stimuli); it tests exclusion run2>run1 after appraisal support.
Although unpleasantness ratings are self-reported, the fMRI contrast is not self-evaluation/agency/self-knowledge; it is neural change to exclusion across runs.

Appraisal manipulation targets interpretation of others’ social relationship/intentions in the game; even though peak is subACC (affective), the construct still involves understanding the social situation/others contributing to exclusion, thus social-cognitive/other-related processing is implicated.

Contrast compares viewing dynamic emotional facial expressions vs dynamic mosaic controls during passive viewing. This directly measures processing of socially meaningful facial expressions (a core social cue), engaging social brain regions for interpreting others' emotions.
Task involves perceiving emotional expressions, not affiliative bonding, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship-relevant evaluation (e.g., loved one vs stranger).
Viewing facial expressions constitutes receptive facial social communication (decoding affective facial signals) compared to nonsocial mosaics.
No self-referential judgments, agency, or self-knowledge components; participants passively view external stimuli with a dummy detection task.
Primary demand is perceiving and interpreting others' emotional states from dynamic faces (understanding others). Contrast isolates social meaning vs nonsocial dynamic motion.
Stimulus type effect (expression>mosaic) assessed separately within emotion conditions (anger/happiness) still indexes social processing of facial expressions vs nonsocial controls.
Manipulation is emotion category, not affiliation/attachment bonding or relationship constructs.
Within each emotion, contrast tests receptive processing of facial affect communication vs mosaics.
No self-related processing required; emotion factor pertains to stimulus, not self-appraisal.
Emotion-specific expression processing reflects inferring others' affective state from facial cues.
Stimulus type effect (expression>mosaic) evaluated with participant sex as a factor still measures social processing of dynamic facial expressions vs nonsocial controls.
Sex modulation does not make this an affiliation/attachment task; no bonding/relationship manipulation.
Receptive facial communication remains the core process; sex is merely a between-subject moderator.
Does not involve self-knowledge/agency; sex is demographic grouping, not self-reflection task demand.
Perception of others' emotions from faces is the core contrast, regardless of sex effects.
Expression>mosaic with emotion and sex factors still tests social processing of emotional facial expressions relative to nonsocial dynamic stimuli.
No affiliation/attachment construct assessed; factors are emotion category and participant sex only.
Assesses receptive decoding of facial expressions (social signals) and its modulation by emotion/sex.
No self-referential or agency judgments; moderation by sex/emotion does not constitute self-perception task.
Inferring others' affect from faces is central; emotion/sex are moderators of that other-focused processing.
Laterality analysis on the expression>mosaic contrast evaluates hemispheric dominance for social processing of dynamic facial expressions versus nonsocial control stimuli.
Laterality of expression perception is not an affiliation/attachment measure; no bonding/relationship stimuli.
Quantifies hemispheric dominance for receptive facial communication processing (facial affect cues) vs mosaics.
No self-focused processing; laterality pertains to processing others' facial expressions.
Laterality of processing others' emotional expressions (action/mental state cues) is directly assessed via original vs flipped contrasts.
Emotion-by-laterality ANOVA on expression>mosaic examines whether social processing lateralization differs by emotion category; still within social processing domain.
Emotion modulation of lateralization is not affiliation/attachment; no relationship/bonding manipulation.
Tests emotion-related modulation of hemispheric dominance for receptive facial affect communication processing.
No self-perception component; factors relate to stimulus emotion and hemisphere.
Concerned with perceiving others' emotions from faces and how that is lateralized across hemispheres.
Sex-by-laterality analysis of expression>mosaic assesses demographic modulation of hemispheric dominance for social facial-expression processing.
Participant sex differences do not operationalize affiliation/attachment; no affiliative/relationship task.
Focus remains receptive facial communication; sex is a moderator of lateralization.
Not self-referential; sex is grouping variable, not self-perception task demand.
Assesses lateralized processing of others' facial expressions, potentially differing by sex.
Emotion-by-sex-by-laterality model on expression>mosaic still interrogates social processing of dynamic facial expressions and its modulation; core contrast remains social vs nonsocial stimuli.
No affiliation/attachment construct; only emotion, sex, and hemisphere factors.
Evaluates modulation of receptive facial communication processing/lateralization by emotion and sex.
No self-related judgments; factorial moderators do not change task into self-perception.
Processing others' emotional expressions and how it depends on emotion/sex and hemispheric dominance.

Participants viewed human faces (disfigured pre-treatment vs same faces post-treatment) during a gender-judgment task; the contrast measures neural responses to socially relevant facial stimuli differing in disfigurement, which is a social evaluative cue.
Task involves passive perception/categorization of unfamiliar faces and does not assess bonding, attachment, affiliation, or relationship formation (no loved-one/kinship/cooperation manipulation).

Although faces are stimuli, the task/contrast is not about communicative signal exchange (e.g., emotion recognition, gaze, expressions) but about disfigurement salience during gender categorization; thus it does not directly measure social communication constructs as defined.
No self-referential judgments, self-knowledge, or agency manipulation; participants judge others' gender.
Contrast involves perceiving and evaluating properties of other people from faces (social perception of others; disfigurement influences trait/empathy-related processing even under cover task).

Same face-viewing gender-judgment paradigm; the decreased responses (pre-treatment vs post-treatment) reflect modulation of social-cognitive/empathy-related regions (e.g., ACC/mPFC) by socially salient facial disfigurement.
No manipulation of attachment, affiliation, social bonding, or relationship contexts; stimuli are unfamiliar patients' faces.
Contrast is not about decoding or producing communicative facial/nonfacial signals; it is a salience/outgroup-related perceptual manipulation during a simple gender decision.
No self-focused or self-evaluative component in task/contrast.
Measures neural responses to others' faces varying in disfigurement, engaging perception/understanding of others (social evaluation/mentalizing-related processing differences).

Decision phase of prisoners' dilemma (cooperate/defect) is an explicitly social decision-making task involving interaction with (putative) other players; thus measures social processing broadly.
Prisoners' dilemma operationalizes cooperation/competition and pro-social affiliation-related behavior (cooperation choices) toward others.

Although opponents are represented by faces, the decision-phase contrast models choosing cooperate vs defect rather than processing communicative signals (e.g., facial expression/gaze, communicative acts). No explicit social communication contrast is tested.
Task does not require explicit self-referential judgment, agency attribution, or self-knowledge evaluation; it is primarily about choosing actions toward an opponent.
Decision-making in PDG entails evaluating the opponent/other player's likely behavior and social intentions (mental state inference) to guide cooperation/defection decisions.
Result phase involves perceiving outcomes of an interpersonal (social) exchange in prisoners' dilemma; processing social feedback/outcomes is part of social processing.
Outcome feedback reflects success/failure of cooperative interaction (mutual cooperation/defection/being exploited), directly tied to affiliative/cooperative behavior.
Result screen is payoff feedback, not communicative signal processing or exchange of socially relevant messages (no facial/non-facial communication reception/production modeled).
Outcome perception is not an explicit self-reflection/self-judgment contrast; it is external feedback about game results.
Interpreting game outcomes depends on understanding the other player's choice (cooperated/defected) and attributing intentions in a social exchange context.
Patient-group (FLE) activation during PDG (decision/result) reflects engagement in a social interaction task; thus within broad social processing.
PDG in patients measures cooperative/competitive behavior and related neural responses, fitting affiliation/cooperation construct.
Per-group activations are not tied to explicit communication processing contrasts; task is economic decision/outcome rather than communicative exchange.
No explicit self-referential processing contrast; per-group maps reflect task engagement rather than self-perception.
Even within a single group, PDG requires evaluating another agent’s behavior/intentions; patient maps reflect this other-oriented processing demands.
Control-group activation during PDG (decision/result) reflects performing a social interaction/cooperation task, qualifying as social processing.
PDG captures cooperative affiliation-related choices and their neural correlates in controls.
No explicit analysis of communicative cue processing; contrasts are decision/result phases rather than facial/non-facial communication reception/production.
Not an explicit self-perception task; activations reflect social decision/outcome processing rather than self-knowledge/agency judgments.
PDG engagement in controls involves reasoning about the opponent’s likely choices/intentions; thus perception/understanding of others is implicated.
Main effect of group compares patients vs controls during a social task (PDG) across conditions; captures group differences in social processing-related activation (e.g., MPFC).
Group differences arise during cooperative/competitive interaction context, reflecting differences in affiliation/cooperation-related neural mechanisms.
The tested effect is group differences in task activation, not communication-specific processing; no communicative signal contrast.
Group main effect reflects overall task engagement differences, not self-referential processing specifically.
Because PDG requires evaluating others’ actions/intentions, group differences (e.g., MPFC) plausibly index differences in understanding others within the task context.
Main effect of condition (decision vs result) is computed within a social interaction task; contrasts phases of social decision-making and social feedback processing.
Decision vs result phases in PDG pertain to cooperation/competition behavior and its outcomes, central to affiliative/cooperative processing.
Condition effect contrasts internal decision vs outcome feedback; does not isolate reception/production of communicative cues.
While decisions are self-generated, the contrast is not framed as self-referential/agency evaluation; it is task-phase related.

Both phases involve interpreting the other player's behavior (decision strategy; outcome indicating other’s choice), so the condition contrast still reflects processing of others within the social exchange.
ROI main effect of group (superior/medial frontal regions) examines group differences during PDG; this is a social-processing-related ROI analysis.
ROI group differences are probed in the context of cooperation/competition task; thus relevant to affiliation/cooperation-related neural processing.
ROI analysis targets frontal ROIs for group differences, not communication cue processing per se; no communicative contrast.
ROI results are not based on explicit self-referential judgments; they relate to task-phase activation in a social exchange.

Frontal ROI differences during PDG likely relate to social inference/mentalizing about opponents (understanding others) required by the task; correlations with trust ratings support other-oriented processing.

Participants observed goal-directed hand actions versus control hand movements (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS). This is a social-perceptual task engaging action observation/perception, a core component of social processing broadly construed.
No manipulation of affiliation, bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition, or attachment-related cues; task is action observation without relationship context.
Task does not involve communicative signals (facial/non-facial communication reception/production); it contrasts goal-directed object actions vs non-goal-directed movements.
No self-referential judgments, agency attribution about self, or self-knowledge components; participants passively observe others' actions.
Action observation (goal-directed hand-object interactions) requires perceiving and interpreting others’ actions/kinematics; the contrast isolates action perception of others (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS).
Same ActionOBS–CtrlOBS contrast in an independent sample; measures social perception via observing others’ goal-directed actions vs control movements.
No affiliation/attachment manipulation or relationship-relevant stimuli; only action observation.
Not a communication task; no communicative intent/signals are contrasted, only goal-directed action vs control movement.
No self-processing component; contrast concerns perception of others’ actions.
Directly indexes perception/understanding of others through action perception (goal-directed actions vs non-goal-directed control).
Experiment 3 repeats ActionOBS–CtrlOBS; observing others’ goal-directed hand actions is a social-perceptual task within social processing.
No bonding/relationship, cooperation/competition, or attachment constructs are assessed by this contrast.
No communicative exchange or decoding of communicative signals; contrast is action observation vs control movement.
No self-referential/agency/self-knowledge judgment; participants observe others’ actions.
Measures action perception of others (a subcomponent of Perception and Understanding of Others) via goal-directed action observation contrasted with control observation.
